number of helpful: 40 of 55 people (73%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crea is another entry in the recently extremely popular 2D Sandbox genre. However, Crea is unique in that it acknowledges the roots of all this popularity, Terraria, and tries to build off of that with unique new mechanics while still trying to retain that core gameplay that we all know and love (or don't; it's all up to personal preference of course).For those who may not be familiar with the genre, Crea plays like most other 2D Sandbox RPG sort of games. You walk around a randomly-generated landscape, clicking on blocks to collect them, killing enemies along the way. As you gather more varied and rare materials, you are able to craft various items, including weapons, armor, furniture, tools, and a few other miscellaneous items. To be able to learn how to craft most of the items however, utilizing the research system is necessary. To research more advanced crafting recipes, you need to use a small quantity of each material you find to discover what uses you can make of them. This system was pretty neat in my opinion and I would love to see it become a staple of the genre.There are essentially three different ways of dealing with enemies in Crea: melee weaponry, ranged weaponry, and magic. Personally, I love using magic to sit back and pick off enemies from a distance, There isn't a large selection of magic or weapons, but there's still an adequate variety of them to dispose of any monsters in your path. There are also "Divine" spells that help to assist you with positive buffs or give some well-needed healing in dire situations.From a glance, Crea seems to be actually almost a direct rip-off of Terraria, just with a somewhat different art style. This isn't really true though, as Crea includes some great new additions to the typical 2D Sandbox game formula. To start with, Crea includes the usual gear-based progression system of acquiring new, more powerful weapons, tools, and armor as you acquire better, more valuable materials. Something possibly unique to Crea is its "talent system", where as you engage in combat, use spells, craft items, or research recipes you gain "TP", which can be used to boost each of the previously mentioned areas a bit. The more that you mine for example, the more TP you are able to gain to potentially make mining just a tad quicker. One thing that did bug me a bit when I had first started was that mining seemed to take quite some time, but after I crafted a snazzy new pickaxe and upgraded my mining talents things went much smoother.One very unique aspect of Crea is the "conflict" system in place. If you don't actively slay monsters, they will continue to grow in strength and numbers throughout the world. This was very noticeable when I had played, as I immediately went on multiple mining expeditions early on and never really fought monsters above the ground until I had the gear that I wanted. When I finally had crafted all the gear that I wanted to take on (supposedly) anything in my path, I discovered that when I came back to the surface new "Paragon" enemies that were larger and more deadly than the previous enemies had appeared and were proceeding to kick my♥♥♥♥♥♥ Monster spawners had also appeared quite rapidly throughout my world, and these were generating more and more monsters to add to my growing problem. This system is quite cool in my opinion, as it creates a unique conflict for the player personally- do you sit safely in comfort and idly gather more materials, or do you engage the problem at hand before it becomes harder and harder for you to safely stroll out in the world? In addition, monsters actively level up as you do, so there's never really an overly easy battle in Crea. Bosses are also in the game I've heard, though I have not encountered any in my time playing so far.A fast-travel system is additionally in place in Crea. As you explore your randomly-generated world, you are able to find Way Crystals that allow you to travel immediately to another crystal in the world that you've already found. These Way Crystals can also be found underground, which is convenient if you're able to find one while mining deep below the surface and want to quickly travel between your home and your mining area.Two features of Crea that I didn't delve very much into are multiplayer, which is supposedly new and thus has some early issues, and the extensive modding support the game includes. I did join one multiplayer server I had found from someone who left their IP address on the forums, and it was a bit of fun, but the multiplayer system did seem to be in its early stages for sure and there was a few small problems. The game currently is still in Early Access of course, so there's plenty of time for it to be cleaned up a bit more. I would like to see player names not just in the chat, but also above the players or maybe if you hover your mouse over them, and perhaps a basic server browser for those of us who may not have friends who also own the game or want to go hunting for public server IP addresses. Concerning the modding support in place, I honestly haven't delved into it much so far, but glancing at the forums on the developer's site, they seem to be very active in assisting any players wishing to create mods for Crea, and the system in place seems to be fairly easy to make mods to do nearly anything in the game. So far, no major mods seem to be out yet, but as the game is still fairly new hopefully fairly interesting mods are released.The sound design of Crea doesn't seem to be a major focus, so there's not much to say about it. The sound effects are basic, but they work. While not overly prevalent, the music featured in Crea is alright. I would prefer to be listening to more active tunes, but the current set of peaceful, calming music is still pleasant to listen to.Graphically, Crea features pixel sprites very akin to that of Terraria or Starbound, but with a slightly more fantasy theme. Two things in particular stand out, to me at least: the designs of the monsters and the backgrounds when above the surface. The monsters all have a fairly unique look to them- to the degree that it's difficult to relate most of them to something we're familiar with. Sure, there's some scorpions, sheep (called "speep" in the game), and birds, but also some very unusual bird-like creatures, rodents, sinister slimes, and even odder things deep beneath the surface. Most of the monsters seem to fit in perfectly with the fantasy theme of the game, and it helps to increase immersion for sure. Now, while not overly incredible, the backgrounds as you move from biome to biome above the surface are pretty to look at, and help to differentiate different biomes as they gradually change to a new background as you move from left to right or vice versa.While others may argue which is the best of the 2D sandbox genre, it's important to note that most of the games are still in-development and can't be fairly judged. Crea is likely one of the youngest games in the genre, and so it's difficult to fairly assess it in its current state. As it is, I really did enjoy my time with Crea. I was able to build a small home after a few hours of mining. I had fun with defeating monsters of varying strengths and sizes, and exploring the vast world I was in. I don't think that I've even begun to dig deep into the amount of content Crea has to offer, and thus I'm not if I can safely say how much I might potentially enjoy it. The game is also still in Early Access as I write this, so the amount of content and features that are in the game currently can only increase as time goes on. The developers are extremely active, and seem to have a great knack for talking with the community very often and answering any questions people may have on the forums. This is a game with a lot of heart and soul put into it, and so it appears that any issues the game might have will quickly be ironed out.I give Crea a 8.5/10 in its current state.

												I'm going to be blunt and honest. This game is fun, it has a worthwhile system. Everything you do grinds towards experience, you have a combo system on weapons and you have some neat magic. But, at the same time, it's still only worth being called an "Early Access" game. 1.2? And the 30? It's there for a second before dropping back down to ten, if not lower. I wanted to like this game, I really did. I played till I even had silver gear! But I can't do it, it's too laggy.The developers do have a good idea of what they're doing but, as a lot of people said, the 'bosses' aren't worth doing. Dungeons are bland. Once they improve on the content and performance of the game? It's worth getting. But as it stands you'd be better off buying Planet Centauri, and it's still in beta. But Terraria is even better.If you can get it for cheap, and I mean less than $5, then I'd say Crea MIGHT be worth it. Otherwise? You're be better off looking elsewhere.

												In a word: Disappointing.Crea is yet another early access game that was put on Steam way too early only to be released in a state so bad the game feels rushed and unfinished. Fact is, Crea has been in development for years yet still feels unsatisfying to play. The dev remains active but so what? He obviously can't deliver. Why even bother having the cycle?There is no threat, no driving goal and no reason to build a base.Base building is clunky as heck.Even opening a chest will make your ears bleed...

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review- version 0.24.0 authored 08/12/2015I've played Terraria and Starbound. I honestly like both. Terraria especially was one of those watershed games for me that got me really excited for something different than I had played before. Somewhere along the way, Terraria stopped development. Later, Terraria began development again, but the original team was different. Because of this, my personal opinion is that Terraria is missing that certain something that makes me both want to keep playing, and to play again. My personal opinion is that Terraria just never reached it's full potential (yet).So why am I talking about Terraria in a Crea review? Ultimately, we tend to compare things as human beings. Terraria is the single most likelt comparison when looking at Crea. So the foundation of my opinion is partially based on what I didn't like about Terraria, wheras listing the good things about Terraria is less germaine to a Crea review.Let's make some of the obvious comparisons between Crea and Terraria; both are side scrolling 2D sandbox action/adventure games. Immediately you notice that both require chopping down trees and killing slimes for a primary ingredient needed to make torches. So very quickly it's impossible not to notice near identical design choices. Beyond some of these simple things though, we start to divert from the earlier same-genre games and Crea makes it's own niche.The glaring differences of Crea are still under development and that's an important thing to know at this point. Things like crafting research, which is required to progress and craft, actually may change to a smaller or larger degree; that is the nature of in development software. Moving forward, it's still important to realize the design goals that differ in this game.I mentioned research that is required for progression and to craft. It's not my purpose to expose the full mechanics in this review. I also feel it's part of the enjoyment of this game to experience these things for yourself. Suffice to say that the research system puts the player on a path that makes progression inherent in the game, regardless of your play style.To compare and contrast with Terraria, for the most part the player would only need make or find certain crafting tools, such as a forge, in order to unlock all recipes of a certain type. The crafting and, indeed, the exploration of Terraria comes down to mindless time sink, especially the first time through. In Crea, the system is more robust. It can feel grindy, but the game is actually slowed down. Nice tools like teleportation (which I'll not spoil by explaining) are therefore not overpowered as they provide the nice time saving boost they should be instead of just speeding up and already fast crafting progression like in Terraria.I hate to gloss over very important features like the RPG style level up systems, but again I don't want to spoil the discovery a new game brings. Just know that your character levels up from a traditional XP system from defeating creatures and other hostile entities. In addition, there is a "talent" system where you gain separate talent points and corresponding levels for each of several categories, including arms (melee and ranged weaponry), syle (magic), gathering (mining, forestry, other gathering), crafting (both crafting and research) and exploring. All activities earn TP (talent points) that can be spent to buy active and passive abilities. Again, I don't want to spoil too much so I don't want to give much info out here. Just know that some things like how well your mining tool works is partially tied to your experience using such tools as gained through gathering talent points. So it's not just a matter of getting a better pick. A better pick helps, but your character improves through experience as well, which makes the game more enjoyable for me as I progress regardless of whether I've stumbled on enough of a certain resource yet or not. Also, mining some of that dirt and stone actually pays off as you occasionaly earn some TP for it!Crafting on it's surface is very generic to the genre. However, there is a still-in-development system called "Chaos Crafting" which is really a sort of boosting mini-game. It is off-putting to some folks. It is not required to craft. You merely have the option to invest more time and some special resources to try to improve your crafted items. I have only dabbled with this system and I don't quite get it, but I look forward to using it in the future to make better items as I progress. Again, this is another example of game mechanics that slow the game down a little bit, add some challenge, depth, replayability, discovery and... fun!Speaking of fun, ultimately we play our games for the fun we have. If you play Terraria and liked it, you'll probably like Crea. If you felt Terraria was just not what you wanted, and you want a more RPG style game that has a little more organized progression, you'll likely prefer Crea. If you want to zoom to the end of the game in Terraria and despise climbing the progression ladder, best to stick to Terraria. If you're just not sure. then it comes down to the cost.Just to touch on the cost, I always felt Terraria was too cheap to not buy. I agree that EA games that are "too expensive" are not something I generally interested in. That's all a discussion for another place. But, Crea's price at this point is certainly open to criticism. For what it's worth, I don't think the dev's are really pushing their product, I really think their actions so far have proven they really just wanted some dedicated people willing to buy in that will help development. With the features available so far and the development pace, I'm personally very happy to buy at the current $15 US price.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Monday, June 13th, 2016 Review As a 2D sandbox RPG, it's hard not to compare Crea to Terraria. Despite a somewhat similar pixel-art visuals and side scrolling adventuring, Crea has a lot to offer to be it's own game. While not a huge fan of the genre, I have still found the time spent so far to be enjoyable.Crafting is done by learning recipes through researching the different elements  you gather from exploring, or that you craft from the base materials. It's also nice that you're using the same blocks to build the side and back walls of your buildings. Combat is dynamic and doesn't feel too one-dimensional with various creatures fighting you in different ways. Some of them are also peaceful and won't attack you unless they're getting attacked first. The leveling and skills are interesting and the points you gain to spend in there areas are amassed through experience. If you're mostly avoiding fights, don't expect to have much points to spend to improve your fighting skills.This can be a bit problematic sometimes because, in the case of fighting, it takes a bit before you can craft decent equipment so you might struggle with the wildlife when trying to explore the world in search of crafting material for research and building. It's hard to fight until you get the hang of it and some decent equipment ans skills, and it's hard to improve your skills and equipment if you're having trouble exploring and dying from attacks. Some type of monsters can only be found in certain areas so you sometimes need to grind for items that you need to explore a different area. (Like gathering wood and oil to make torches before doing some underground exploration.)While the game adds elements of lore that you can find through your explorations, the content feels a bit thin. There's also little to no explanation about some elements of the game (like teleport crystals) and you're left to find out for yourself what they're for.Overall, the game has enough to offer for fans of the genre. With the limited content, it's probably better to have people to play with to make the experience more enjoyable, but even as a single player game it's easy to sink quite some time into this.Rating: 7.6/10 Pros: Recipes are learned from researchDynamic combats which requires varied strategiesRPG elements with stats and skills progression.Relaxing music scoreAbility to mod the game Cons: Content is a bit thinA bit hard to get startedSome things are confusing and aren't explained.The GUI can get in the way at timesNo dedicated server for multiplayer Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege Games

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been playing the Crea beta since the third phase started and Crea was available to all Kickstarter backers. The game has a lot of potential, and in a market that has spawned a lot of Terraria style of games, Crea manages to have its own unique style and feel that helps it stand apart from the crowd. Early game progress is slow, and the learning curve is a little steeper than something like Starbound, but once you've managed to get nice gear and delve deep into the underworld you feel as though you've accomplished something.One big selling point of Crea for me, that lead me to back the project on Kickstarter in the first place, was the concept of developing from the ground up for complete mod support. The code is all exposed so the community will be able to help shape the game long after the initial release.While Crea has run into some development issues in the past, Jasson and Kelley have been active in the community and open and forthright during the entire process.If you're a fan of Terraria and felt that Starbound didn't quite scratch that itch Crea might have what you're looking for. I've been playing the game on the DRM free version, so my Steam time played is deceptive. I've probably put over a hundred hours into various characters across the different builds of Crea since I started playing several months ago, and imagine I will find myself playing quite a bit more once the multiplayer functionality is a bit more stable. Multiplayer is where games of this nature, in my experience, really shine.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a borderline recommendation for a game that looks and plays like Terraria and Starbound. However, this game does have some things setting it apart. The main difference is the RPG elements attached to it, where you can basically level up everything and even acquire new skills. Yet while the game has some neat features going for it, it also does some things wrong. And it is for that reason I can't recommend this game for everybody, so read on and/or watch my video to find out if this game is for you.


YouTube™ Video: Crea Quick Look 

			Views: 3,794		

			Noble of Lost Pause plays Crea, a 2D sandbox game currently in early access. To put it simply, combine an RPG and Terraria together and you get this game.		

For those who want the basical summary, here's a concise pros and cons list of my thoughts.+The RPG elements of leveling your skills to make you fight, mine, and even craft better is very nice. You're not even limited on what path to take, so you can take every bonus you want for melee, ranged, magic, or building. It doesn't matter.+The sandbox world keeps you wondering what is out there and encourages you to explore. There is even plenty of caverns that lead into the depths of the world, so you don't have to mine everything over and over again.+By far the best feature I've seen from this game is the ability to use materials in nearby chests when you're crafting. No more sorting or looking through chests to find that one monster drop you picked up long ago. The game automatically senses you have it, and you just hit the craft button.+There's only one tool you have to upgrade that chops down trees and mines. You're not forced to choose between axes, pickaxes, or hammers.-The mining in this game is an absolute chore. It takes forever to mine out a path through the earth or ores, even after upgrading your tool a few times. It just drags the game out needlessly. The fact that it's only one block at a time and you have to set your mouse directly on it to mine doesn't make it any better either.-In order to craft things, you have to first research all the parts in order to make it. I actually liked this at first, but then my opinion changed after the first hour since the researching costs you the material, so you have to keep farming the same thing over and over again. Throw in the fact that you have to keep tossing away the same item multiple times for different recipes, and you're just gonna find yourself in an awkward place like I did where I was on the verge of making progression, but I either lacked a material to make the item, or I lacked a material to research so I could make the item. Combine it with the above negative and the fact you don't know what the item may be, and you got yourself in an annoying situation.-The monster spawn rate in this game varies way to much. Often times I never get a single baddie for ages, even when I'm mining deep down. This is terrible because you need a drop from a certain mob to make torches, but when you can't find it and run out of torches, you're forced to go all the way to the surface again and farm a monster that is sometimes a pain to find. But then there are times where my screen starts getting swarmed, and not with the mobs I wanted.-Some of the abilities are really underwhelming. I wanted to be a mage and maxed my fireball spell. Now while it did do more damage, the spell was just rubbish. It has cooldown of a few seconds that makes it really awkward to use. The animation finished in the blink of an eye, but for some reason, your dude can only stare at his enemy and let himself get wailed upon. Combine it with the paltry damage it does and the mana bar that limits its use, and spells become really worthless. Heck, the ice and fire spells both function the same to but only have a different sprite firing out. And when I found out my crappy copper dagger did more damage then my maxed spell, I just gave up on being a caster.-Because of the above, this game has a terribly slow pace. After 4 hours of playing this, I feel like I barely got anywhere, and it's not a good feeling.So yeah, you may be wondering why I recommended this game after the big negatives I listed. Well, it's because I still enjoyed myself somewhat. I wanted to explore more and find out what skills I would get and what the world had to offer. That's the mark of a promising sandbox game.But to be perfectly clear, I believe you can only enjoy this game if you liked a really slow, relaxed experience. If you want something more exciting, then I strongly suggest you go to terraria or starbound. But just keep in mind that this is early access, so maybe the devs will change the pace, or maybe they won't. So if you're still on the fence, it may be best to wait until this gets released. This has the potential to be up there with the big hitters, so I hope to see it go places.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												I originally gave this game a negative review, but that was a mistake. I found that exploring and terraforming (digging a lot everywhere) was my key aspect. The main developer (Jasson) was very kind and honest about asking me questions about my review. This game, however, is still progressing, but so far it is just amazing. Now, I will move onto the pros and cons that I have thought of.Pros: - Developers are very kind and nice, (I have read forums and I have seen Jasson and a few others responding, which I thought was very generous.) - Has a great RPG style, with its variety of abilities, armors, and weapons of choice. - Exploring and digging were 2 of my favorite parts about this game, because that's just the type of player I am in games. - Bosses are actually tough no matter how far you are in the game, which adds for a neat challenge, where you will actually have to strategically find the pattern of the bosses attacks and learn how to avoid them. - Game has much variety. (Ores, weapons, armors, etc.) - Weapons/Armor/Tools do not break, which got me about 11.50% more into this game. - Artwork is very cool. Cons: - Still in progress, just needs more bosses and enemies.  - Grinding sometimes takes a while and is lengthy, but the reward you get is great. - Game is a bit slow, in terms of framerate, but as long as it runs, I'm ok. - Researching is a bit tedious, due to having to use materials to research items that use those materials.Overall, this game is still progressing, but what it is with right now is just absolutely great. The developers and community are also amazing. Overall, just an amazing game as it is.8.7/10

number of helpful: 31 of 47 people (66%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
Product received for free
												Crea is a cute sandbox RPG with procedurally generated worlds that is heavily inspired by Terarria; therefore, if you enjoyed playing Terarria, you'll probably have a lot of fun with this one too. Even more so, since Crea extends what Terarria offers with a few new features that are very entertaining and nice.One of the most important features is the leveling system: everything you do in Crea gives you experience points, categorized by what you do to gain them. The XP are not added only to your character level, but they're also split according to the action you perform: exploring will give you XP in the Exploration category, mining or cutting wood will give you XP in the Gathering area etc. In addition to that, there's a talent system - according to the level you have in an area, you can unlock passive or active abilities that make your character stronger or increases your gathering or crafting skills.The two main aspects of these kind of games are split in two separate interfaces - there is a setup for survival mode (combat) and another setup for the gathering mode (building); each of these setups comes with two separate toolbars that you can customize according to your needs. Switching between the setups or the toolbars is very easy (one key press). However, having this kind of design makes it a bit difficult during early levels to perform both combat and gathering during the night, since switching to combat mode makes you lose the only source of light you have, leaving you in complete darkness to fight with your enemies, unless you put down a torch every few steps. This problem falls away at later levels by the time you acquire luminescent weapons or a spell that conjures a light orb that follows you.The enemies are of various types and come with different fight mechanics: some of them should be meleed from behind, others can be killed easier using ranged weapons. This makes good use of the double toolbar setup for the combat mode, since you'll need to have both a melee set of weapons and a ranged one. I found the difficulty of the enemies at lower levels a bit too high, even on easy mode - they do a lot of damage; you need to parry or dodge a lot since the majority of them can kill you in 2 hits.Crea has Dungeons, how cool is that!!! Independent areas on the map, that despawn after completion, dungeons provide a lot of fun and... very cool loot(since you can snatch all the goodies and fill your house with shinies) :)The crafting aspect of the game is extensive; you can craft the plain old way, by one-clicking (oh and by the way, crafting with this method is instant, there's no progress bar or waiting time until you get your desired item). As an alternative to that, the game features Chaos-mode, which is a mini game that makes use of crafting talents gained through leveling in order to produce better or more items. The crafting recipes are discovered by researching but you are only able to research recipes you have mats for. On one hand, this limits your crafting possibilities to items that you have mats for. On the other hand, you can't see a full list of everything that can be researched; if you want to craft a fancy item, you won't know in advance what you need to gather in order to research it, unless of course you spoil it for yourself by consulting the Wiki.The clean interface features moveable windows, which is very useful while crafting, either for organizing your inventory and the needed mats or for comparing the stats between the crafted gear and the equipped one. However, even with these moveable windows, I found it quite annoying that I don't have any indication when a mob attacks me while having my screen full of these windows. I believe that a blinking screen or a red border would be very useful in this case.The basics of the game are summarized into a short and concise tutorial; the information that it provides is in my opinion enough not only to get you started, but also to make you understand the mechanics of the game; the rest is left to the player's own exploration.Apart from some small bugs that didn't disturb my gameplay enjoyment too much, I had only one problem with the game: it consumes quite a lot of PC resources despite the fact that it shouldn't; the lighting or having multiple things happening in the background is very CPU hungry, often causing spikes; after 3-4h in game my PC already starts to struggle with the high CPU usage and tabbing out doesn't help it at all. Since the developer is quite active in the forums, I have faith that this optimization issue will soon be addressed and fixed.I had a lot of fun playing Crea so far. I feel that it's a wonderful and well designed game that is worth the asking price. For the nice graphics, hours of entertainment, Steam integration with achievements and workshop, I highly recommend this game.Note: A key has been provided by the developer with the request to write an informative review. No other consideration, compensation or instruction was received. My personal opinions about this game are not influenced by this.More reviews on the Lilly's Corner Curator page

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I am someone who liked Terraria. I liked Minecraft a lot, too. I love open world games that are full of exploration, lots of things to do, and lots of loot to drown yourself in. 2d side scrolling games like this tend to be called Metroidvania games. I first got Crea many months ago and it was rough, unpolished and hard to play. I waited. MANY updates have come out since then so I decided to give it another try a few weeks ago. I am glad I did.Crea has an in-depth crafting system that actually takes a bit of thought to figure out. You don't just have materials, you have crafting methods. They call it Chaos Crafting. There's a variety of crafting techniques to apply while you are crafting something. It's up to you to find a combination that works well. If you do, you can get some amazing results. The enemies in Crea are likewise as well thought out. You can't just run up and whack and enemies like you do to Terraria's slimes. Enemies in this game have different attacks, but they all have certain patterns that you can figure out. What the game needs most is variety in what the player experiences. Once you craft that next tier of armor and weapons you're off to do more of the same, just in a higher level area, battling the same monsters who are simply higher level. The game does have biomes, but as of this review, they're only surface biomes that don't mean a whole lot at the moment. However, the game is solid enough and enjoyable enough that the $15 price tag is well worth it at this point. Combat is a blast in this game. Since development is still very much underway who knows what we might see for the biomes or maybe even new, different underground zones. Crea has a ways to go before it could be a contender for king of Metroidvania Mountain. It's not there yet. It's got a ways to go. But it's certainly headed in the right direction.

number of helpful: 14 of 17 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
Product received for free
												Review Written on Sunday, June 5th, 2016 Review So, Crea is a 2D Sandbox rpg sorta like Terraria, Edge of Space, or Starbound. However it's not just another clone, it has similarity but has its own unique way of playing. So you start of with basic tools and weapons, typical stuff you'd find in these sorts of games. However, You have and attack and build/gather mode which you can swap in between. It takes some time to get used to that, tho is a really nice feature when you get down to it. You have a hotbar for both combat and build, so you don't have to have a gather tool or block in your combat mode bar. You can also have 2 hotbars for each mode, so you can have a different set of weapons and skills. That being said, you gain experience for each thing you do, like killing mobs gives you combat exp, crafting gives crafting exp etc. Once you gain enough exp you get talent points which are used for various things like new combats skills, or skills to help you mine faster etc. There is fair amount of skill, so I won't list them off. As you progress you character gains stats, standard rpg mechanics. You can add points for more health, stamina, strength etc.The combat, is well not the greatest but not bad either. You swing in a upward motion which is kinda odd, other then that its fine. You also get magic, which uses your stamina bar. I haven't done very much magic but it seems really cool. Combat could use a bit of work, tho. The sound effects for it are kinda lacking, however they are planning to add more in later.Now on to the crafting, pretty standard stuff here gather materials and build. However, you'll need to research items in order to build new ones. Some thing require, one item to research other take more as you discover items. Once you research and item you can craft it. When crafting you can also add modifiers to it, not sure how it all works yet as the tutorial doesn't really help much. There is much more to do, and much more I haven't discovered yet.Final thoughts, Its a pretty good game if you are into like Terraria and such games. However it does have a few bugs, and bad frame rate at times. Those are likely to improve as patches come out. The game releases soon so you can either buy it now or wait.Rating: 8/10Pros: Replay value, since you can build your characters differentlyConstantly UpdatedLots of contentSkill progression, gives the game more of sense of accomplishmentMultiplayerCons: Combat is okMissing textures sometimesBad frame rate dropsSome bugsCrafting and researching needs to be explained betterLack of sound effects, which they are going to add.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't usually write reviews, TL;DR at the bottom.From what I've played, It seems pretty great to me. The RPG/Explorer is a sucker thing for me. I love how the crafting elements is so immersive, you must research in-game to figure out how to craft new things. The combat system has multiple spells and it's own specific point system. (I.E Style has Style points and Craft has its own Craft points.)This may be odd, but I'm sensing a backstory on the whole world of Crea. For example, why is it when I hover my mouse across certain things, various letters are scattered, seemingly like they're missing? Who is Renma? Why is a feather a sign of forgiveness?There are 2 modes in this game, Build and Combat. You must press R to switch in between which is a bit annoying, but with time you'll get used to it. Also, the graphics are absolutely beautiful for a pixel game. Now, there are some bad things in the game. For example, the beginning enemies can be WAYYYY too diffucult if you're difficulty is set to normal. Most of the Ink-slime thingies are level 7 straight off the bat, while you're stuck at level 1. Other than a couple few annoyances (rarely happen), it's a well polished game.Also, kudos to the developer for being so helpful and responsive. I read about a guy who watched his stream, and the Developer was taking reports for bugs live on stream! I love it when developers feel like they're actually there, unlike most developers. *cough Chucklefish *cough*Another thing I'd absolutely LOVE is more in-depth on the story. How was the world of Crea created? Most of the ingrediants in the game have some lore attached to it. (I.E The Renma core or whatever it's called) Little notes scattered across the terrain or in caves would be absolutely amazing to have since it intrigues the player to discover and explore more.TL;DRWant an upgraded version of Terraria? Want a developer that actually gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥ Want a (somewhat) intruguing lore and backstory? Want a level-up system that actually matters? Want a combat system that lets you fight however YOU want to fight? Want a beautiful game?Then go for this. Prepare to be a little annoyed though at some bugs (I.E Character not showing on create screen), but it's in Early Access so it's alright.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
Product received for free
Crea is a 2D procedurally generated sandbox RPG. It finally left “Early Access” and I was excited to try it out. The game requires many hours of gameplay to be able to explore it fully. This is my first impressions review after playing for a few hours.Let’s start with the good stuff:Crea’s visuals can be described as “cute”. Colorful 2D pixel graphics. Everything is a little bit too tiny (I preferred to play with 150% zoom) but overall looks good. Music is nice and relaxing. There is a lot of content: a huge world to explore, tons of skills to learn, recipes to find and items to craft.Crafting system is pretty extensive but beginner friendly. There are so many items you can create and build. It is not available right off the bat. You unlock it by leveling up and researching recipes and materials.  Combat is challenging even when playing on “Easy”. Especially in the beginning before you get a chance to upgrade your character and find or craft better weapons and armor. Unique monsters with different attacks and behavior. Some are very aggressive and will attack the moment they see you, the rest will only attack if provoked.Developer is very hands-on with regular updates, progress reports and even Twitch streams. I recommend watching those if you want to learn more about the game and the people behind it.Steam Workshop support (modding is highly encouraged). Steam achievements, cards and badges. Here is what I didn’t like:My main problem with the majority of sandbox games (and that includes Crea) is a lack of proper in-depth tutorial. There are a couple of tips at the beginning of the game that only explain very basic mechanics. Everything else you have to learn on your own, usually by trial and error. Some quests or tasks on the early stages of the game would make learning process much more entertaining. This game needs dedicated servers for multiplayer or more convenient way to play with friends (or strangers). Right now you can only connect to someone else’s server by typing their IP address. Some minor bugs. I haven’t encountered anything game breaking. I am giving Crea a thumbs up. It offers fun and addictive gameplay with virtually endless replay value. If you like sandbox games, I don’t think you’ll be disappointed by this one.PC Specs   Hardware Type   CPU Intel Core i7 5820K 3.30GHz   GPU Nvidia GeForce GTX 970   RAM 16GB DDR4   OS Windows 10 PRO  Disclaimer: A copy of the game was provided by the developer (Siege Games) for reviewing purposes. However, this did not influence my review in any way.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Sunday, June 12th, 2016 Review This game is an open-world sandbox game, similar to Terreria, Starbound, and the like. You can get randomly generated small, medium or large worlds in single-player or multiplayer modes. Lots of effort went into the crafting and gathering portion of the game, as well as the world itself and all the monsters you can encounter. Sometimes I die too easily, but usually that's my own fault, I need to be more careful.I enjoy how much there is to do in this game, you can discover so many different monsters, items to gather, ways to die, and so on that you can play in one world for a good while. The music is pleasant and the sound effects aren't bad, kind of sparse though. The graphics aren't bad, and I like that even if you have a higher resolution monitor you can use zoom to make things easier to see, otherwise the world is way too small at the higher resolutions.I consider this game a well polished and interesting hybrid rpg/sandbox/open-world game in the same vein as others that came before it. If you enjoy these kind of games, it is worth the asking price for it. Also the developers are active after this game left early access, so they definitely care about polishing the game even further. Overall this game is well worth money and I highly recommend it. :)Rating: 7.8/10 Pros:  Great open-world sandbox gameplay, with lots to do and see. RPG style system where you level up and can learn different things to craft and gather inside the game world. Talent system to allow to level up all kinds of different skills and abilities you can use. A massive amount of content already in the game. I like the zoom feature with higher resolution graphic settings it allows your character and the world you are in to be bigger and easier to see.  Cons:  UI needs a little more polish, it seems that items arent well organized and quantity of items for crafting is not very obvious. On multiplayer, when I do an attack or receive an attack, it seems to lag for some reason, so the projectiles or melee attack stutter somewhat. I think this just may be related to a lagging server. Best to play this game on a keyboard and mouse. So far the controller is hard to use in comparison.Game gets a little repetitve after awhile, but it keeps it interesting with some variety.The craft system could use some more intuitive UI adjustments and polish, overall it's pretty decent though. Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege Games

Review Written on Tuesday, June 14th, 2016 Review Crea is a 2D RPG sandbox type of game, the pixel style graphics are rather pleasing to look at although I would have love them to be a bit bigger but thats just me since it doesnt really change anything to the gameplay. You can choose between small, medium or large size world. Even the smallest one is quite big and has a lot to explore. Theres tons of things to do in this game, the crafting section has a lot choices. Like all game of this type theres two mode building and fighting (or survival). You wont see the time pass while you play this game, you can easily sink many hours into it and never get bored. The addition of Steam workshop add tons of options, the possibilities are endless. And since the dev are really active, I have high hopes that future update will add even more content. One thing I usually complain about is the lack of tutorial in those games, but not in Crea the tutorial is pretty good at explaining the basics, although I would have liked to see it explain more in depth. At the moment theres no dedicated server for multiplayer, so that might be a problem for some as its very much the kind of game you would want to play with others. Rating: 7.5/10 Pros:  The tutorial is covering the basis pretty well The integration of Steam workshop with modding will add lots of content and gameplay The RPG elements (leveling, skills, etc) add an interesting side to the game The procedurally generated world are quite big and theres lots to explore The devs are very active and theres frequent updates.  Cons:  Theres no dedicated server for multiplayer which in this kind of game is a downside Theres are still bugs, but the devs are pretty active, so it should be worked out The graphics are a touch small for me, it was hard to see details very well While the tutorial take care of the basis very well theyre still a lot of aspects that would deserve more explaining   Hardware Information   Hardware Type   Monitor Asus laptop 17 inch 1600 by 900   Headphones Headphones   Keyboard Asus ROG laptop   Controller XBOX 360   Mouse Microsoft mobile mouse 3500   Microphone Microphone   Motherboard ASUS ROG laptop   CPU Intel Core i7 6700HQ 260 GHz   GPU gtx 960m 2b   RAM 16 gb   OS windows 8   HDD 1 tb  Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege games

content:

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Friday, June 10th, 2016 Review Crea is a cute pixel like game much akin to Terraria. You harvest items like trees and minerals and then research these items so that you can craft them into different objects. There's a lot of exploration to be done which involves walking on the surface of the world or digging below. Beneath the surface you will find creatures, different kinds of minerals and treasure chests. The treasure chests can only be opened with keys that you can find by smashing pots or even by picking the locks using a lock picking skill which can be acquired by leveling up. There are lots of other skills you can acquire in different categories. If you explore a lot then your exploration XP increases and you can spend those XP on different skills to do with exploring like jumping higher or running faster. If you fight a lot you can use the XP on different skills to level up your weapons etc.. I have started to enjoy this game now but I have to say that you need to be VERY patient and do a bit of research into how this game works. The GUI is a bit confusing when it comes to crafting and in my opinion it is just harder to craft things than it should be. Perhaps its because I have never played a game like this before but I found it really difficult to work out what to do to start off with.Some people like the fact that you have to work out what to do whilst others prefer knowing from the off how to do things. I had difficulties with equipping items I had created and found the whole crafting side very frustrating. After 5 hours of playtime I am starting to figure out the procedure. First of all harvest your items whether its by chopping down trees, killing monsters or digging the ground. Eventually you will have enough resources to craft a research bench. Once that is crafted you can research into the resources you have found which will give you recipes for new items i.e. better weapons, furniture,spellls etc... Once you have these recipes you need to craft a work station to build them. If your inventory is full and you craft the item then the item will fall to the ground! You can buy another inventory bag or craft a chest to put your things in though, however I havent found enough resources to craft one yet.I think there is going to be a lot of grinding in this game to get the resources you need to research and craft items to eventually explore further away lands. The further away you venture from your starting point the more difficult it becomes and you will find yourself being killed by one hit of a flying fishes tongue or something. Once you have upgraded your character and have better armor and weapons then you can expand your horizons a bit and even visit other worlds through teleporting through the crystals that are laid out throughout the world. The graphics are nice if you like pixel like sprites and the music is relaxing and calming. The game got released yesterday and Jasson the developer seems very nice and responsive to any suggestions you might have. Overall I would say that if you like these types of games then it is a very good example of one. It has a charm about it and you find that you can play it for hours and not get bored. Try not to get too frustrated with the crafting side of things. It may seem frustrating and baffling at the time but you soon get used to it and then you will find that you proceed quicker. Even though there is a basic tutorial system it is not enough to answer all of your questions I found and I had to research the internet or ask friends how to do things. This is an area I think can be improved on. The game is quite difficult to start off with and you will find that you wont be able to venture too far away from your starting point without leveling up and getting better weapons. With Steams refund policy theres no excuse not to try it out though just be careful that you don't accidentally play over 2 hours as this game has a habit of devouring your daytime. Rating: 7.5/10 Pros:  A good example of a Survival/crafting typed game with nice pixelated graphics and sound. This game has charm in buckets and there are loads of nice touches throughout which keep you amused and entertained. The developer is always releasing updates too! The discussion forum is lively. Good Customisation including character design and choices of worlds. Multiplayer or single player options The game has Controller support although sometimes this doesnt integrate well with the mouse and options.  Cons:  The Crafting system is over complicated and the GUI needs a little rethinking. A Lack of tutorials to tell you what to do. Controller support seems to be a bit glitched with menus and it is difficult to dig solely with the controller. I found I would use the controller to move and fight but would use the mouse to dig. content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
Review posted on Thursday, May 16th, 2016Crea might be summarised as a Terraria with light RPG features. Much like how Terraria was heavily inspired by Minecraft while promising major changes (and using a different engine), there are substantial differences from Terraria, including a different engine approach with Python-based moddability. The standout features are a leveling and research system with stat points and magic spells, and it includes the vast bulk of features players are used to from Terraria. The controls, crafting, fighting, digging and exploration make one feel right at home, and all the expected elements are in it and often expanded upon. Building elements and armor are largely the same, but different tool types have been simplified away. NPCs are 'crafted' too in an interesting system where you equip a neutral mannequin with a specific suit to assign a role to it.Unfortunately much like the afore-mentioned games this is inspired by, it's very much a game that hides many crucial details from you, forcing the player to play with out of game help like a Wiki. Whereas the initial items Terraria or Minecraft shipped with had very clear tiers, that isn't the case here. A bronze tool may have a specific upgrade part later on, while perhaps a bone one does not, and that isn't shown in the UI besides by mouseovering every known recipe.Experience gain is handled via a 'learning by doing' system, where fighting gives you combat XP, crafting gives you crafting XP; ditto for magic, gathering, exploration – and all of those have separate levels and unlocks (talents) that you pay for with points gained from leveling. Regularly these unlocks come in the form of active abilities for your quickbar, and you will quickly run out of space for them.For the combat, common RPG features like dungeons and mob spawners join familiar features like bosses, but unlike in Terraria and the like, you will rarely actually use health potions and mostly rely on a healing spell fueled by your combined stamina / mana bar (shared between attacks, dodges, spells and so on).Inventory management is once again a matter of coping with your very limited amount of slots, which themselves store an ungodly quantity of their particular items. One neat feature however is that you can craft using items stored in nearby chests, as well as use a forge you are not standing directly next to. In Terraria it's always a bit of a needless fetch quest to grab the materials you need to craft from your sorted chests and walk to the right crafting station. Another convenience option after a few hours of play is obtaining extra inventory space in the form of bags, which sadly then can't be viewed all at once.Crea is quite jolly for people who enjoyed Terraria, but isn't gonna win over those who didn't.Rating:7.4/10Pros:lots of perfectly functional contenthas everything people love from Terrariamoddable (warning: mods disable Steam Achievements)frequent updatesfree, non-grid item placement instead of only placing items in blocks"Terraria with a twist"Cons:not very original ("Terraria with a twist")need out of game help or a lot of trial and error to cope with the crafting and progressiona good few graphical bugs and glitches remainpoor combat AI pathfindingHardware InformationHardwareTypeMonitorSamsung SyncMaster P2470SoundSennheiser HD 580 and Samson Resolv 80a SpeakersKeyboardMicrosoft Siderwinder X4ControllerMicrosoft Xbox 360 WirelessMouseLogitech G400MicrophoneKoenig Electronic CMP-MIC8MotherboardGigabyte X58A UD3RCPUi7 920 at around 4 GHzGPUGeforce GTX 670RAM12GBOSWindows 7 64-bitHDD2x 1TB RAID HDDA review copy of this game was provided by the developer.

												Disclaimer: i recieved this copy for free to write a review about the game. However this will not influece my review. Source of consideration: Siege GamesCrea is a sandbox rpg game with a lot of farming, digging, gathering and exploring. The graphic is simple 2D graphic, however its not bad.Heard from friends, that Crea is a Terraria 2.0 game. I do own Terraria, but my library pretty huge so not had time to play that game yet, i cant confirm that information.Crea allows you to level your character in many different ways. Your gathering, crafting, arms skills, spell skills and alone your hero get different experience and all these have different leveling system. Reaching next level on those experience trees unlock purchaseable abilites/boosts for your character. So you can see, character development is pretty deep in Crea.You cant craft any item you want right away. you need collect materials/ingerdients and then you need study those items, research them and then develop what could you craft from those. Sounds painful? its not, its fun, even if the research process destroys the item. New armors, weapons, building materials will be available as you progress through the game and as you research how to create those items, Crea offers a long and enjoyable gameplay while you build up your character, its house and clear hostile fauna.Sadly i not had much time to play Crea yet because of Euro 2016 and Copa America, but i allready love it and would recommend to anyone, its a pretty decent game for its genre, developer definetly spent a lot of time on it and one of the few games on steam what actually left early access and now officially released! Additionally, Crea has an affordable price which not much compared to the playtime this game offers.Pros:+deep character development+deep item research system+multiplayer available but you can enjoy single player just as much as multiplayer if you prefer that+the random generated worlds are huge, you have a lot to explore, monsters grant you hard, challenging figths+some might dislike this, but map shows suggested levels for areas so you can avoid areas where you would encounter much stronger enemiesCons:-i have some issues with combat. magic casting too slow, melee much faster and stronger, it might change later as character evolves, ill keep an eye on this and will update review.-i need to further investigate the reason but sometimes i have lags and performance issues what i shouldnt have as my rig much-much better than requirements.Overall rating: 8/10 for the genre however i not seen any better game for this genre yet.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
Short Version:  *whistling* Heigh-ho, Heigh-ho, it's off to work we go...We dig dig dig dig dig dig di---AHHH IT'S A FLYING ROCKET PIG!!! Aw nuts, it flew into the house!!  I *told* you not to leave that hole in the roof for 'easy jumping access'!  KILL IT! KILL IT NOW!     -- Sir Spud, Digger Extraordinaire and Slayer of Crea-an Rocket Pigs. Crea is a 2D RPG-ish sandbox game featuring digging, exploring, crafting, building, and fighting - all the usual sandbox shenanigans - with the addition of skill points to add a whole new layer of character progression beyond the usual gearing-grind. The game starts you off on a random stretch of a vast, procedurally generated world filled with multiple biomes, both on the surface and underground.  Each biome has its own set of dangers and rewards, containing scary monsters, hazardous dungeons, and all the shiny rocks you could ever want in order to build the castle of your dreams.Crea's main enhancement to this basic sandbox structure is a skill-progression system to improve your character (in addition to the usual process of finding/crafting better gear).  As you perform any activity in Crea, you gain skill points which you can spend to become even better in related talents - digging gives you points for gathering skills, fighting allows you to invest in combat skills, etc.  This allows you to improve your character over time, and also focus on whatever niche you prefer, be it a warrior, a magic user, or someone who just reeeeally likes digging holes.  Crea also features a few other uniquely nifty ideas to build upon 2D sandbox-crafters of yore, such as dungeon portals which can buff the monsters - or nerf you - in random ways to create a truly challenging experience.  There is also a clever research system to gain access to better tools, deadlier weapons, and snazzier furniture - which is a nice way to limit starting players to necessary items early on, while providing plenty of extra choices as you progress through the game.  While Crea has quite a bit going for it, there are still some issues to be aware of before you commit to that 'buy' button.  The natural downside to the extensive amount of progression that Crea offers is that the game is not exactly newbie-friendly.... at all. There is very little tutorial to go on, so you will likely need to make quite a few side-trips to the forum before you become comfortable with the game - or even to get familiar with the controls, which are not always intuitive. The game's visuals will also probably displease some users - the 2D sprites scream 'indie title', although in the end they get the job done just fine.All-in-all, Crea is a neat addition to the 2D sandbox-crafting genre, with plenty of extra features to make it stand out from similar titles.  If you're new to the genre, Crea is a fine way to spend potentially endless hours exploring, digging, fighting and building, though you should read up a bit on the game first to make the start a little more pleasant.  Meanwhile, for those simply looking for a game to fill that Terraria-shaped void in your life after playing it to death for the last few years, Crea will certainly do that and then some.  Received a free copy for testing/reviewing purposes.

												I will continue to update my review as I play.Crea came out of nowhere and blew past most of the games I've played. Don't miss out on this gem. The soundtrack is amazing and the art style is grabbing. So far this game has been VERY user friendly for me. The hud/layout is easy to navigate and butter smooth. The tutorial system as you play is very helpful and won't leave you blind. It's easy to get familiar quickly. You gain TP through different categories depending on what you do (fighting, magic, exploring, crafting, harvesting/mining I believe, etc.). TP can be used in each of these categories to purchase talents (active & passive). Also, you gain xp from creatures you kill. The combat is crisp but I wouldn't call it fluid. When you level up, you gain stat points you can distribute with about 7 or 8 different options (att, def, int, luck, agi, stamina, etc.) which I love because that's really what makes every character different (all talents can be maxed by any character but stats are unique). Anything and everything is destructable & craftable. The most similiar game to Crea is Terraria which I enjoyed playing.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												In may 2011, terraria was released, pioneering the 2D sandbox genre. At its time it was a pretty minimalistic game with no story and limited content, but over the years it gained more and more content that eventually made terrraria one of the most underpriced games on steam.With the success of Terraria, other developers began taking an interest in making their own 2D sandbox games. There were a lot of promising ones that went into early access, but they quickly found themselves unable to compete with terraria that already had a good headstart and was continously being updated. Those that did make it out of early access have all been failures.... that is until now. 5 years after the release of terraria, Crea has just become the first good 2D sandbox game to be released since terraria. Crea is better than terraria in some ways but also worse and I will explain in detail all theseHere is how Crea is better than terraria:- Crea has a backstory that gets revealed as the game progresses.- Crea has slightly better graphics.- Crea has a leveling up and research system that creates a sense of progress and pretty much eliminates the need for a guide NPC.- Crea has a tutorial that helps guide the player in the very beginning. luckily, the game is fairly intuitive once you get used to the new system in comparison to terraria.- Crea has better native modding support than Terraria.- Crea does not require a wiki in order to play and discover the world on your own.Here is how terraria is better:- Terraria is underpriced, crea is fairly priced.- Terraria has more content, although this could change since terraria has reached its limits whereas Crea will continue to get updates going forward.- Terraria performs better, lower PC requirements, more optimised code.- Terraria's music is slightly better.- terraria's controls are slightly better.All in all, if you are looking for a 2D sandbox with a more RPG feel to it, Crea is recommended over Terraria. If you are a fan of terraria who is looking for something new but similar, Crea is recommended for you. If you want more freedom in what you do in the game, dislike a RPG progression system, or want a lot of content then terraria is recommended over Crea.

number of helpful: 23 of 38 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Crea is a game I really want to like.  I helped kickstart it years ago, and have been following along with the development.  It has a lot of good things about it, but plenty of bad, and right now, I cannot in good concience recommend this game.Of course, there are bugs.  Many of them, though I have only been stuck by graphical glitches, unlike some.  I expect the major game-breakers will be resolved in the next few weeks, so I won't "mark off" for that.  The major gameplay areas of concern for me are combat, research and the "fun" factor.Quite simply, combat is too hard and unforgiving.  This is related to both the monster-leveling, which makes the same mobs get strong and stronger as you move away from your base (and it does not take long before they one-shot you), and the odd combat upgrade system in general.  As there are no visual variations, an oil slime that you can easily kill in one area is instant death elsewhere.  This makes for frustrating play.  The intent is for you to level yourself and your gear, and grind to become better.  Unfortunately this is not obvious, and makes the game exceptionally gear dependant.  I could never add enough health, attack and defense via leveling to make up for the wrong tier gear.  The combat system itself seems to be more geared towards missile weapons and hopping and dodging, as even fighting correct level mobs is a 1 vs 1 affair.  The monster-leveling system ensures that facing a few mobs at a time is likely death.Research is the second major flaw in the game.  At its core, the idea is that you research items you find and unlock recipes to make things.  Sounds good so far.  The problem is that there is essentially no guidance or progression.  You're left to your own devices to randomly research items you find, craft random items on the off chance it is something that will be researchable and unlock something else, and stack up piles of items for potential future use, because even if you have already researched an item, you may need to use it again for something else when you level up your "research trait".  Overall it is a confusing mess, that doesn't add much to the game except situations where you have copper ore and a forge but cannot smelt it because... you need vines?  Multiple that by hundreds of item combinations and you begin to see the issue.It may be the above items, or something more subtle, but the game does not really feel "fun".  It is interesting for a litlle while (5 or 10 hours) while you figure out the mechanics of the system, but it's not deep enough or polished enough yet to hold my attention.  All of this said, I do want to like the game, and it is a far improvement over what it was like a year or more ago, so I have hope that the developer will take this sort of feedback to heart and the game will improve.  I'll keep my eye on it and update this review as patches change the gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
												I'll start with the obvious. Crea is a sandbox RPG, which has a lot of similarities to Terraria. Crea is more about the characters personal development through levelling up and talents, along with weapon and armour upgrades. Crea also has a really cool research system behind the crafting. You need to find the pieces of what you want to make and research them to discover the recipes they can be used in. You can also use scraps (that can be easily obtained from research) to discover parts of the recipe without using the components you have. The crafting system goes even deeper than that, by using "Chaos" to imbue your items.Crea feels good to play, the mechanics all work well together and nothing feels too clunky. There are a few inconveniences, like being unable to use skills unless you're in combat mode. However the trade-off for that one is that there is a toggle for combat and building/exploration, which is a huge quality of life advantage. The world looks good, and there is some good variety in the biomes, items and enemy types.Crea shouldn't be written off purely as a Terraria clone, it's a game that takes the fundamental idea behind it and produces a fantastic experience. Having said that, if you liked Terraria and want something similar, this is definitely your best choice.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Honestly this game isnt finished but it's still great if you're into the whole Terraria style game. I like this game more than terraria but havent played it as much due to it being early access and all. The heavier focus on the RPG system is what attracts me alot more. There are tons of ways to build your character with the TP (basically skill points) you get, the magi system has been taken down a notch, though I guess it was kind of complicated before. But like I said. You can be a mage, you can be an archer, you can be a fighter, you can be a tank wizard, you can completely avoid combat by just running fast and jumping high. I havent played very much this patch and I dont know if you can still do it, but I used to just stack defense and use the fire aura spell and things would kill themselves on me. The gear crafting is pretty interesting though I'm still not 100% sure how to get the best outcome of it. You an apply different skills when you make an item to give it better stats, but you can use them in different orders for different possible outcomes. There are a good amount of effects you can get on your items such as just raw stats, bonus damage/defence and things like life steal. I hope this gets added onto for things like effect procs such as "x% chance to cause an ice explosion that slows enemies" or "this shield has a x% chance to block 100% of incoming damage" ect.The combat felt kind of stale when I first started playing, but you can get better combos by investing skill points in certain weapons and what not, you can block which applies your shields defense somehow or another, not 100% sure how it works. You can dodge roll behind things when they try to hit you. But you have to moderate your stamina the whole time or you'll become exhausted and not be able to do much other than walk slowly and jump until your stamina refills. It's honestly a pretty good feeling system. Early game it might feel annoying if you get in a big fight but when you get some more stamina it's not so punishing to just go ham on things. One thing in particular that I really like is that there are portals that spawn that take you to instances like dungeons or just a big area with lots of enemies and sometimes spawners to kill. I havent run into a dungeon yet, that was just recently added but you get some pretty nifty rewards for doing so if I remember correctly. If not just the rare drops that enemy spawners drop.Anyways, the devs update this game alot, I miss the old complicated as heck magic system with tons of different spells, but the new one is still fine and dandy, there are lots of new skills added to other trees such as combat, crafting and exploring. Building is pretty good so far though it's not what I really look forward to doing in these games, exploring is pretty solid, enemies are diverse, there are bosses (which are just bigger badder versions of smaller things) that will randomly spawn and likely wreck you. I think it's very worth buying or adding to your wishlist and keeping an eye on. I straight up love this game and cant wait for it to hit full release.

Posted: June 14, 2016
Is this another clone of Terraria or Starbound, let's see, shall we?There is no point for me to blindly copy what is already in the description of the game because it is exactly what it says there. But the main element in this game is the focus on RPG leveling. With everything you do, you gain accordingly TP (Talent Points). This makes you being really good at things you do the most. You also gain normal levels and distribute points into various attributes. This helps/restricts you with the level system for using items, talents and crafting. That brings us to Crafting. Crafting and researching was pretty confusing for me in few moments. You can't just craft or research things even if you try to check for recipes in research on what you can research and you think you have all the ingredients for it. There is still need for checking google and guides for these situations you will be stuck in. On the other hand, I really liked the "Chaos" crafting, being able to enhance items with more potential abilities, making it magical.Gathering things is pretty much same as with other games of this genre. Except you have teleportation system ready at hand (after you discover waypoints - Crystals). Time spend gathering is also lowered by the ability to mine more than one square at the same time, you'll unlock this ability early in the game. You'll get 4 loadouts, 2 for each combat and exploring/building mode, it proved as being very effective after getting used to it. Inventory is pretty small, but you'll also unlock more after few hours of the play and then you'll have plenty of it. Building and architectural enthusiasts will be happy about options on how to make your home look fancy. I was never much into spending many hours decorating my "house", but if you like this sort of thing, you'll be thrilled.Visuals of this game are really polished for this type of genre, even animations aren't just the simply rotating items, anchored on one side, just like in Terraria, such a nice change. Music is pretty nice and calming, I really enjoyed it. Other sounds are really just basic or there aren't any at all where they should be, which is such shame for a game that is out of the Early Access. SummaryHopefully developers will continue adding much more content, so this game can become true rival. Should you buy this game if you already own any other game similar to this? I would say no, unless you really want to try something else or you're building type. However if you don't own any similar game, I pretty much recommend it.Rating:8.2/10Pros:Character progression - Put points into Level TalentsEnchantments? ENCHANTMENTS! - Chaos crafting is really nice touch.Other worlds - Dungeons and realms. So you aren't just on one limitedQuick travel and mining - Say goodbye to long trips back and forth. Mine more than one square at same time, don't be a mining monkey!Possibility to name things and other customization - Naming waypoints and storages is very convenient. You can also most of the GUI windows around.Mod supportCons:Occasional lags - Although I only died once because of that.Story is not much engaging - It just lurks somewhere in the backgroundResearch and crafting confusionSometimes no sound effect where you would expect oneHardware InformationHardwareTypeMonitorSamsung 40 LED 3D TVKeyboardC-TECH NereusMouseGenius NX-7000 RedSpeakersCreative Inspire T5400 5.1MotherboardGA-A55M-DS2CPUAMD Athlon II X4 651KGPUGigabyte Radeon HD7770 OCRAM8 GB RAM (Kingston)OSWindows 10 Professional (64bit)HDDSSD Samsung 850 Evo 250GBGame was provided by Siege Games but it didn't influence my review in any way.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crea is an interesting take on the 2D sandbox genre established (or at least popularized) by Terraria. It goes without saying that the game features mining, crafting, and building systems that are found in similar games, but there's much more to Crea that makes it stand out.First, there's research. Instead of being able to craft items as soon as you have the materials, in Crea you need to do research first. This is a really cool mechanic, because it gives the sense of having your player tech up. It also gives the player an urge to explore the world and see what it has to offer, instead of telling the player that they need x, y, and z material right off the bat, and turning exploration basically into a grocery list.The monsters in this game are also really cool. They are all unique and adorable. Also, there are no zombies, which is always a positive in my book.The teleportation system system is awesome as well. There are way points throughout the world, called "Way Crystals," which allow for a fast travel sort of system. This is nice, because it allows you to jump to specific points throughout the world while being able to go back to your base to empty out your inventory from time to time.If you decide you like Crea, but want something more out it, I should point out that Crea is built from the ground up to make modding as easy as possible. You can add anything you want to in this game, so I guess if you really want zombies, there could be a mod that lets you put them in.The community behind Crea is really awesome, too. The forums[siegegames.com] are full of people giving feedback on the game and providing support to new players as well. The devs are also active on the forum, and will add features to the game based on community discussion.All in all, I think that Crea is definitely a game worthy of your attention, especially if you like games like Terraria. Even if Early Access is something that makes you uncomfortable, I would recommend that you keep your eye on Crea. It has amazing potential, and I think it would be a shame if you passed it up now and never came back to look again later.
