content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
Product received for free
 Crea is an extremely enjoyable sandbox game, the engine is vibrant and the game play is solid and enjoyable. The game offers an immense amount of content as is expected of the genre, yet stands out in the deliverance of it. Everything is well organized and simplified in a friendly UI, so unlike some other games the players are not overwhelmed or lost in endless lists of craftables and items. First off, I will need to point out the obvious, Crea is extremely similar to Terraria which is a well beloved and commercially successful game, so it's hard to do the same things Terraria does and do them well. Fortunately, Crea does not disappoint. The environment in Crea is lush, varied, and suitably deadly. There are mounds of things to collect and make, loads of enemies to face and challenging bosses to tackle. The controls in the game are responsive and have not yet caused my demise by being obtuse. The controls are fully map-able, and allow for both kb+mouse and controllers for those who feel they need them.Crea has been stable since launch, both for single and multiplayer modes, and has kept me entertained by the many adorable and very-dead-because-I-need-mats critters it has thrown at me. The developers patched and ironed out most of the reported issues soon after the game's release, as well as continue to make weekly tweaks and fixes in the game. Showing how closely they monitor feedback from users, always nice to know that the products we use will be well maintained.The game itself is simple enough to understand and get into; Most things in the environment can be gathers and used as materials for crafting weapons, clothing, structures etc. There is a level system which governs what items are available for crafting, as well as a skill system which uses accumulated points to unlock perks, passives and improvements to existing mechanics such as movement, gathering speed, combat prowess and so on. As a general rule sandbox games do not have a final goal or destination, but I suppose getting the bosses could be something close to that. Sadly, despite the tutorial, people who have never played a game in this genre might take a little while to get up to speed in Crea.Pros: Rich environmentNice soundtrackHandles nicely and allows for control customizationWell maintained by the development teamOffers hour of fun in solo mode or with friendsImmensely rich in contentAddition of RPG elements to the game allows for more to do than the standard harvest/craft cycleCons:Can be unfriendly to beginnersOccasional minor FPS dropsSuffers from the usual sandbox game issues such as having to collect hundreds or materials to make 1 itemEnemy AI could use some polishingAll ‘n all, I struggled a lot trying to think of cons and had way too easy a time enumerating the pros in Crea, which is rare for me. I highly recommend this game and would give it an easy 8/10Source of consideration: Siege Games

Early Access Review
								First of all, I bought this game a few hours ago. I do generally like 2D adventure/sandbox games, but that is definitely not the only reason I like this game. It is already pretty unique and I believe it will only become better. To all of you saying, " Oh, it's just another Terraria rip-off," I say please be quiet! (Trying to be polite :) ) Starbound started off as "another Terraria" but became so much its own game! I believe Crea will, too! Crea is great fun even when it is in a pretty early stage. I do think things can be refined a bit. The things are: a bit more in-depth tutorial because things can get confusing, slightly faster progression and leveling up, and less creature spawners and a creatures spawning more naturally. There are also plenty of good things: unique art style (pixelly yet detailed), unique creatures and world, and a decent pace, especially for those beginning the game, maybe not for ones more into it. I do recommend it, and if you aren't sure definitely keep your eye on it for the future!

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is great, with very few downfalls. It incorporates combat, crafting, leveling and boss fighting. However, being Early Access, it still has some bugs. Multiplayer has many crashes and sometimes the players completely disappear. It's an easy fix by re-entering the game, but it's still a nuisance. Single player is crisp and the combat is really fun, but more enemies should be made. Bosses are the same every time and I would hope for more variety and to have them all a little less linear, right now they're all very "tricky", meaning there's little to no strategy to fighting them. The best and worst part of the game is the crafting. The crafting is very fun as you have to research items to make new gear, but there is just about no direction on how to do it or what items need to be collected to craft. Understand that it's still an early title that needs fixing, but it's a great buy overall. Well worth the full price if you're willing to support developers.

Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016 Review Crea is a 2D sanbox RPG and at the start it took a while to generate the world but once that is done its time to create your character which is pretty basic options but it does the job nicely. The leveling system is nice and you can also use talent points. talent poitns can be earned by gathering materials, mining and chopping trees and such, each talent has different skills that can be leveled up, there is also passive and active skills and you can spend your talent points on the things you want to be strongest at. The overall experiece with skills and the talent points is excellent. Also there is 2 modes which you change with Y, building an combat to makes things easier you just switch to what you need. The world on this was huge and i ran into some problems when i got to far from the start so had to stay close to level up, both physical and magical attacks seem easy to use and worked well. The game reminds me of Terraria by the look of it and i think this will generate a following similar to that. Over the game was very easy to pick and play and using the controller was very easy, i can see this game becoming a huge success and the developers should be proud of their creation. I do feel the price should be similar to terrarias price of 6.99 GBP Rating: 6.5/10 Pros:  basic tutorial is good and gives you a great start to the game Controller support is good, I try to use the steam controller for anything non fps and it was easy to pick an play straight away. i did not try with a keyboard. TELEPORTATION- no need to spend hours trying to get to certain places, something that would put me off usually but this fixed it. Active developer - been many updates since i installed this and more to come. Trading cards for anyone who like to collect the badges :)  Cons:  No dedicated servers. Options menu is limited on the main menu but alot better once the game is running. Lag, my pc seems to lag quite a bit while running this and im not to sure why as the game is not that demanding and i have had other games that require heavy ammount of resources and run fine. Game just will not minimize to windows, if i needed to go back out id have to quit the game completely. Crafting was a bit confusing and i didnt see a tutorial on this, maybe one should be added :)  Hardware Information   Hardware Type   Monitor 32 TV   Headphones turtle beach px3   Keyboard logitech g15   Controller xbox wireless   Mouse logitech mx518   Microphone turtle beach px3   Motherboard gigabyte   CPU hex core 3.4 ghz   GPU radeon 7750 OC   RAM 16 gb   OS windows 10   HDD 1tb sata  Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege games

Early Access Review
Review Written on Tuesday, June 7th, 2016 Review Crea is a sandbox game that is similar to Terraria. You start in a world with a character with almost nothing. The only thing you start with is a mattock and a weapon. Using these items you can gather resources and kill monsters. Similar to Terraria you can build new stuff with the resources you find in the world, but in order to build more advanced items you need to do researching using a Research Desk. Luckily it didnt need to be researched before being built. There are two play modes: build and attack. These can be switched during game play whenever you feel like. But its most likely you need to switch to attack mode when the are monsters attacking you. Each mode have their own hot bars where you can set to the skills/items you want to use at the moment. Skills can be unlocked using experience points that comes from killing monsters, crafting stuff and etc. There are huge amount of skills to unlock and I believe that in the end you will have everything unlocked. If you really like Terraria, then Crea is the best alternative game. The tutorial could be better, as I played it I had to rely on what I learnt from Terraria in order to progress further, apart from the research and skill leveling part. But the game is really fun to play. It feels like Crea has lots of replayability.Rating: 8/10 Pros:  Its a sandbox game! Nice graphic Huge replayability Crafting, researching and skilling There is a multiplayer mode!  Cons:  Lack of tutorial, it was a lot trial and error Kinda long loading times  Hardware Information   Hardware Type   Monitor THOR Display IPS LED by Fujitsu 23   Headphones Siberia V2   Keyboard Steelseries APEX Raw   Controller Xbox One Controller   Mouse Kanai   Microphone -   Motherboard -   CPU Intel i7-3770K   GPU Geforce GTX 670   RAM 16GB   OS Win10   HDD 120SSD 2TB HDD  Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege Games

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
Product received for free
Review First of all, this review is going to be based on the few hours of gameplay time I have, most of which was spent experimenting with the very basic mechanics. I'm sure there are many, many more features than those I have come across, but I assume it would require a considerable amount of time spent playing the game for me to experience those. So, let's get right into the review. Crea was fully released a few weeks ago. It has a concept extremely similar to that of Terraria, Starbound and other 2D exploration games, but is unique in some aspects. As soon as I started up the game, I noticed it has a very appealing menu, although simple. Upon creating my character, I began in the centre of a large, randomly-generated world. The graphics are cute and an in-game tutorial is available. I must admit, it took me a while to work out how to harvest trees because of the two modes - building and combat - which are merged into one in other games. One of the downsides to Crea is that despite the integration of a tutorial, some things are quite hard to discover how to do - well, for me anyway. I must admit, I still haven't worked out how to place wood. Some things that makes Crea unique is its research, talent system and spells. By crafting a research desk, you can use collected items to research new weapons, armour, furniture and tools for crafting. I also found the talent system quite interesting. Over time, you build up talent points which you can then spend on making harvesting or combat more efficient, allowing new abilities or unlocking spells. By using equipped spells, you can make your attacks more damaging, heal yourself and give yourself other benefits in combat. Overall, Crea is a fun little game to play in your spare time. Hopefully I won't get addicted to it like I did with Terraria. Aside from the frustration when I can't figure out how to do something, I think I will find myself coming back to it time and time again. There seems to be a lot more to do when you get into it a little bit more. Rating7/10Pros-Cute graphics and menu design. -Good, fitting music. -Crafting system tells you what you need to craft the desired item.-Interesting research system. -A talent system that lets you improve your character's skills. -In-game tutorial (although brief). Cons-Difficult to learn how to do certain things. -You have to play it quite a bit to truly enjoy it. -Having to switch between building and crafting modes is a pain when you get ambushed by an enemy. -There aren't a huch amount of character customisation options.DisclaimerI received this product for free from the Developer in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

												A fairly decent game, definitely worth its price. Speaking as someone who hasn't played sandbox games in a very long while:Pros:- Interesting mesh of gameplay systems (chaos crafting, RPG-style progression, sandbox hunting-gathering).- Fairly immersive (when you're not explicitly trying to farm materials or speed-level a character).- Decent (this is very subjective) background themes/music scores... although the volume could be set lower.- Developer(s) are fairly responsive on bug reports & general suggestions.- Great modding potential.- For a 2D game using sprites, the art is quite pleasant.Cons:- The UI could use a LOT more polish.- Some mechanics are not explained (clearly) in-game (chaos-crafting as a prime example), leaving a new player to (slowly) guess what numbers mean what, and what does what.- Can be a bit buggy at times.- Leveling up can be a bit of grind (e.g. hack-and-slash for a bit), but the talent point system (which is not directly tied to the main character level) alleviates this to an extent.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								I sat down Saturday afternoon, that being the 12th of September, and it is now the 13th (Sunday) and since 4:30 pm yesterday up until 7:24 pm today, I have played 16.7 hours.  Yes... I am now an addict!My biggest complaint is that the game does not come with a warning!!!  SERIOUSLY!?!?!?  How was I to know that my entire weekend was going to be sucked in by this incredibly fun, nostalgic (feeling), and exploriffic game!?  For shame I say to he devs!  For shame!Seriously though... I saw screenshots of the game and was thinking "Yep.. it looks like that "other game" there..I read the "About This Game" summary and was like "Yep... been there and done that..."But it wasn't until I read the reviews of the community I have come to grow fond of (STEAM), that I had to at least give it a try.  I mean come on... it seems a drop in the bucket compared to what these folks are raving about...  Surely there is something to this!And so I cracked open my moth and lint encrusted wallet....So yea.. 16 + hours later and I have completely and totally fallen in love with this game.  The character progression... the beautiful (Although a bit redundant music (MORE TRACKS PLEASE!!  ;D  )) graphics and creatures... they give meaning to the at-first-bland character and world you create.  Crafting, exploring, and combat all fall within this realm of fantasy and "incredibility" !!!  And did I just say bland world?  Oh heck no!  Looks like any other "similar game world" ;) doesn't it?  Definitely not.  The procedurally generated worlds are rife with nooks and crannies; treasures and baubles; perils and victories just waiting to be had!I have clubbed Oil Slimes to death in a frenzy...Notched Arrow on Harvesters...I have gathered shards of the "Sunrise" Crystal from whence I spawned to then instantly materialize elsewhere....I have even beaten down the winged Lord of The Birds...  What is next?  Sanos and then?  My friends.  If you have made even one purchase this year... let it be this one.   From Faxanadu and Metroid to Terreria (there I said it) and Starbound... this is without a doubt a 5 star gem that will be talked about (and enjoyed) for years to come!Kudos to the devs,Menoch

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crea is another game in the 2d adventure Sandbox realm. Very similar to Terraria, I would say Crea is most like Terraria as far as a successor, at least so far. Where Starbound is more about exploration, Crea is more about sticking to the core and adding more mechanics. It has rpg like progression where you gain skill points by using that specific skill line. For instance, if you shoot something with an arrow your physical attack tree will gain experience. The same goes for crafting, buff/healing, sorcery and gathering. When they level up each skill line you gain access to new, more powerful skills.It has a big emphasis on researching materials in the world in order to unlock new recipes. You will need to keep exploring deeper and further to progress to higher tier items. The world is very similar to terraria where you can find chests and all kinds of loot in various places. It has a crystal system in the game as a fast travel device. So once you find the crystals you are able to travel between them for a small price. They are located above and below ground. There is also an advanced research system in place that requires finding recipes from monsters.The soundtrack is amazing. Crea has the look and feel of the game down as well. The soundtrack is put together so well, it is very relaxing and perfect for the game style. Very reminiscent to EVE Online's awesome ambient soundtrack. Hopefully they will make it even longer before release. The UI is very slick and easy to use although for the amount of spells/item combinations it does need a little tweaking in my opinion. Having ten hotkeys and then each having a right/left click bind has been done over and over and I would really like to see a new and efficient action bar/UI implemented in this genre. Or at least a big improvement.At this point in development the most you can do is craft the highest ier items and face one boss. I pretty much got as far as that which was 20 hours of gameplay. I enjoyed it thuroughly and am eager to see what they will be bringing to the game by release. Seeing that the game is early on in develoment still and in early access I would give it an 8.5/10. It will have to do a lot of work to maintain or beat that by release though. The game is also highly modable but I haven't checked anything like that out yet.Things I would really like to see before release.The world needs to be filled with different dungeons/exploration triggers and bosses/special monsters. Content basically and it's early access so I'm sure this is in the works. With these 2d sandbox games the funnest part is the mystery of what you could find.I like the skill progression system. But, as of right now the whole thing is kind of pointless because there are no decisions to make. You unlock the next 3 skills and then to level them up until you hit the next skill unlock level. The skills themselves need a lot of polishing as well and they need to, look cooler.The UI needs something to make it more efficient or intuitive. Is it ok now? Sure, but it doesn't improve on the genre's adopted UI or do anything new.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crea is a very awsome and cool game that is "Community Driven" in the sense of the term. It's a game that allows you to do lots of things ranging from fighting monsters and using and wide range of weapons and or magic while doing it. And It also features and in depth leveling system so that you can actually feel progress in game even though the story is "non linear" and let me note that with this game the unique monsters actually scale to your level so that the feeling of challenge is always there. Crea also features a cool traveling system for convience in the form of waypoint crystals which require crystal shard's that can be found surrounding the waypoint crystal that are randomly spawned throughout the world. Also, you can build amazing structures to suit your taste or general feel with plenty of different block types for what your going with for your own customizable character the building possibilties are endless. The game also has a great mechanic where you research thing's to learn how to build them. And lets not forget the  spelunking  you can go into caves and mine for materials with different tiers of pickaxes while also leveling up your mining skill so that thing's can become more convienient as applys to all other things in the game such as Weapons(Arms),Arcane,Gathering,Magic,etc...  And not to forget that this game is also easily moddable and almost everything in the game can be modded. And another thing that makes this game awsome is that it has multiplayer so that you can experience this cool game with your friends to. All in all crea is and awsome sandbox fantasy rpg that is sure to be filling up most of your freetime.

content:

Early Access Review
								Crea is a breath of fresh air in the indie gaming universe.It pulls themes from the genre-builders Terraria and Minecraft and is inspired by games like Dark Souls and Final Fantasy. Crea brings energetic new art and mechanics to 2d sandbox games. With unique crafting, combat, and RPG elements, Crea is a great choice for all those who love a lighthearted mood when playing. Crea is always evolving and changing and its possibilities are endless with its friendly developers and easily moddable interface. The game is in beta however, and there are a few bumps that have to be evened out along the road. The movement can seem a bit choppy, multiplayer is unstable, random bugs, etc. Keep in mind that the devs are constantly working on this game along with the fantastic community.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016 Review Crea is a crafting sandbox RPG that places you in an alien world and tells you to survive. YES, this is a 2D crafting adventure sandbox RPG, much like Terraria. That does not mean that it is the same game, though. A large part of the time spent playing Crea is used to gather materials from above ground, underground, and enemies. While this may sound very familiar and common, it's the rest of the game that truly makes it shine. Crea focuses on small, randomly-generated dungeons that appear throughout the world, each with unique rules that the player must follow to complete them. Instead of a few large dungeons or giant bosses, the dungeons in Crea can spawn any time you destroy and enemy spawn or just randomly on the map. These dungeons range in size from 1-3(+?) floors and contain treasure and a variety of enemies who all want nothing more than to stop you from reaching the exit crystal. Unfortunately for you, you can't just hack away or start exploring, since each dungeon has a unique set of rules that the player must follow to avoid failing the dungeon. Some of these rules include: a time limit, not attacking enemies, invisible enemies, defeating an extra-strong enemy in the dungeon, etc. This makes every dungeon run a unique experience that requires the player to quickly adapt and decide on a course of action immediately upon entering a dungeon. There are also different colored crystals that will take the player to a simpler dungeon that only requires the player to destroy 1-4+ monsters spawners to receive a chest full of goodies.One of the most unique features of this game is that you have to discover crafting recipes by gathering and researching the components that are used in them. Instead of just gathering materials all day and dumping them into chests, you go to you research bench (once you make one) and use the materials you collected to start learning different recipes to help you survive and, eventually, thrive.Another great feature of Crea is the talents system. During gameplay the player receives experience for completing different tasks, such as mining, fighting, and exploring. These different types of experience level up different categories, such as gathering, combat, and exploration and allow the player to purchase different skills or abilities using those experience points. This allows the player to learn everything from new attacks to better weapon proficiency to passive and active skills to double jump and ledge grabbing. These different options allow the player to customize their character in whatever way they see fit to enhance their Crea survival experience.Rating: 8/10 Pros:  Easy to learn crafting research system Random dungeonsUnique dungeon rulesNice, relaxing musicExcellent talents system Cons:  Unclear if there is a major endgameNo simple way to interact with objects (you have to mouse over the object and press a key or click on it)No major boss fights (that I could find)Dungeon rules not easily visibleTutorial is VERY light Hardware Information   Hardware Type   Monitor ASUSMS246H236 x2   Headphones LogitechG430   Keyboard RazerLycosa   Controller XBox360   Mouse LogitechM570   Microphone LogitechG430   Motherboard EVGAX58FTW3132-GT-E768-KR   CPU IntelCorei7-950BloomfieldQuad-Core306GHz   GPU SAPPHIRERadeonHD5770   RAM 12GBCorsairDDR3   OS Windows764-bit   HDD 120GBSSD

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												I bought the game before it was even taken out of early access, and even at that time I would have still recommended it. But now being over 60 hours into the game I can safely say it is currently my favorite game, and I play it several hours a day.Originally the game was really buggy, it still is. BUT, the dev Jasson, is attempting to fix the bugs, every single day he works on this game. He goes into the discussions, and he streams the development on Twitch, where if you have a pressing bug, he will help you right there. Anything you have problems with he tries to resolve all of them. So even if the game is buggy, at least this dev takes his time to address them.He also plans to take suggestions for the game once the major bugs have been sorted out.So don't take it being buggy as something bad, because in time it'll be less and less. Also, sometimes the bugs make for hilarious screenshots(take a look at mine).I bought the game because some friends and I were getting bored of Terraria. This game looked cool, and so we took the chance. We are now all 40+ hours into the game and try to compete with each other to get maxed out. It is an incredibly fun game, with literally so much to do and to learn. It is fun alone, but even better with a few buds.The game is by far, worth it's pricetag. Spend the money, even now with what issues it has. It is worth every cent. Don't be a fool and waste any time not delving into this wonderful game! *Especially if you plan on seeing if it'll be in the Steam Summer Sale (2016), the dev already stated it won't be on sale until the Winter Sale.*

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								As of 8/5/14, and only a couple of hours of play, I have to say I would recommend this game to a casual player looking for something that's lighthearted, fun, and most of all, relaxing. I'm not sure friends of mine would appreciate it's slower tone, but I, for one, love games like these. It does manage to set itself aside from Terraria, Minecraft, Starbound, and Edge of Space---but does so in a way I'm not sure how to put into words quite yet. I love it's focus on RPG style leveling of skills, and how the more you use them, the faster they level, and the more skill points you have to pour into that tree. It's a neat concept in a sandbox game. I think what I love about Crea above all, is the simplicity. It's very easy to unwind in. It's very easy to grasp. I've played related games and the tutorials are just throwing UI after UI at you. As of this review, there's only maybe---4 or 5 main tabs you'll be using besides your hotbar. It's not that complexity baffles me---if done right, it can be wonderful, but in a very specific line of previous games, it becomes a chore and overwhelming. In Crea, things are displayed in a very easy-going manner, at a great pace. The game is what you make it! If you want to sit down, have a little drink and something to eat, and manage things in your house before exploring the deep undergrounds---then go for it! Crea isn't for everyone, but if you want to have a simple and fun time building and exploring, then it may just be for you! I'm glad I picked it up. I hope to follow the devs as they unleash each new update. I've yet to explore Multiplayer, but I'm hoping it's a whole new ballpark!

												If you like Terria, Starbound, or Minecraft this game is for you.  I love this game so much because unlike those other games you can't jump to 10X MAX POWER SUPER GODLY right away. This game is going to be awesome playing solo or with friends.

Maybe in the next update? Lol.My Rating: 7/10

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Crea is a 2D sidescrolling game with building and slow deliberate combat. It is similar in many respects to Terraria and Starbound. It's a decent game for what it is, but it should still be in early access as it is buggy and lacks polish. As it is now, I cannot recommend this game. If you'd like to play a game like this, you're probably better off playing Terraria as the devs there have had a great deal of time to refine the game.Pros+Talent points are constantly being gained, so your character is always improving as you play.+Procedurally generated worlds.+Built in mod support. If the game is able to maintain dedicated players, then it should have a good deal of extra free content.+Skills that enhance mobility, such as sprinting, ledge grabs, and double jumps can be obtained quite quickly.+Fast travel system. Saves you from retreading the same ground over and over again.+When compared to Terraria, digging is more satisfying earlier on due to upgrades allowing the mining of multiple tiles, making it less tedious to dig through areas.+Spells that you are able to access early on make it easy to find ore and chests.+No contact damage on most, if not all enemies, so you can't just take damage by bumping into them.Cons-Visual feedback is a bit lacking on spells.-Enemies are neither knocked backed or staggered by your attacks, making combo attacks less than usefull and making ranged combat seem like an objectively better option.-Enemies are sparse in the underground and tend to ignore you. There isn't much down there aside from the occasional crystal that teleports you to a dungeon, small rooms with chests in them, and of course, ores.-Only THREE options in the settings menu: volume, fullscreen options, and resolution. Sound effects and music aren't even separated, so if you want to listen to your own music or a video in the background, you're going to have to mute the sound entirely, or let the sounds overlap.-I've encountered a bug that has destroyed all my furniture, chests, NPCs, and many of my waystones (used for fast travel). The bug happened after teleporting back from the first(?) boss. I was able to pick up all of the furniture and items in the chests, but the Renma cores (a fairly valuable and rare resource) used to create the NPCs and my waystones were lost. I'd imagine there is a way to create new waystones, but I'm not sure how far along it is in the game.-Very small weapon variety at least in the early game. There are a few different spells, but not many.-Most chests (aside from ones in realm crystals and dungeons) locked and you have to rely on random drops to get keys for them or use lockpicks.-A lot of the gear you get from chests have high level requirements for the time you're able to get them, so you'll be waiting a while before you can even use them.

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been following the Crea development for almost a year and a half, and I cannot express how much I recommend this game.Let's start with you all are probably thinking, this looks like Terraria. Well your right it does. You know the famous quote "Don't judge a book by it's cover"? Look at the game Delver for instance. If you were playing Delver a few years back it was 8-bit, minimalistic. It was a simple game, back then I don't think it was really worth what they were asking for. But now, wow does it look different now! It completely changed. And now comes with Texture pack support so you can change it around even more. That's what you have to think about with early access games, you never know what could change or when! Just because graphically the game looks similar to Terraria does not make it a "clone" or "rip-off", the 2D-pixel side scrollers have been around far longer than Terraria.Gameplay wise Crea feels great. There isn't much in the game when it comes to building blocks or materials, but to me that is a plus. I sometimes feel overwhelmed in Terraria or Starbound with all the blocks I could use to build with. It can get stressful, and I don't want to get stressed over a game; I don't think anyone does. Now keeping in mind this is Early Access, so there is much more to come.Now another thing you are probably wondering about is the "easily moddable" line that is mentioned. Now folks, you can't just hop into a program and make your own mod within minutes, you still need a basic understanding of what to do and it still takes some time. But Crea encouraged me to learn the basics and I've already made a few mods myself. That fact the Crea has official mod support right out of the gate is amazing! Unlike some other games *cough* Minecraft *cough*.TL;DR: This game is astounding, the fantasy-style worlds with the RPG-style character progression fit together perfectly. I'd play this over Terraria any day of the week.Yes this game is Early Access, it has bugs and it isn't finished, that may turn some people away. But it's really great to follow the development of a game and help shape it to where it should go. If your afraid of the developers leaving the game, don't worry. They have built from the ground up an amazing game for over 3 years. If they haven't left yet they are not going anywhere.5/5

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
I would like to thank Siege Games for giving me the chance to try this game and write out a review for them. However, I assure you their action does not affect my evaluation at all.REVIEWA sandbox/crafting game with RPG elements that is almost similar to Terraria, but maybe with a cuter art style. Even with the comparisons, there are still features that make Crea a game of its own. But basically, Crea is more of a laidback and relaxing game compared to the similar games.I would definitely recommend this game to those who loved Terraria and want something fresh. But even if you’re not a fan of Terraria, the game is still enjoyable. Just make sure to be patient since the game does require you to play it for a few hours before you can appreciate it as  a whole.PROS Skill-Base Progression – There are different skills in multiple categories. Your tools, attack damage, defence wouldn’t just depend on the items you’re equipping but it would also depend on how much skill points you will spend on it. Researching Recipes – Before crafting any item, first you need to learn its recipe. And this can be done by using a Research Table and then consuming some materials which will later reveal the possible recipes.Active Developers – They’re trying their best to make this game as great as possible. They care a lot about the game, and you can easily see that through their Twitter accounts or their Twitch channel where they do streams to show you more about the game while listening to some suggestions by the community.Controller Support – It’s not a 100% perfect, but still it is satisfying to use. I still switch to using keyboard and mouse when it gets complicated. The game supports both XInput (Xbox) and Dual Shock (PlayStation) controllers. Neat Tutorials – There are times a specific tutorial would pop up, you can always go to the settings and check out the Tutorial from there. The instructions are all clear and they cover the basic principles of the game. But if ever you need more help, they do have an official wiki page right here[creawiki.net]. CONSSudden Lags – With the graphics this game has, it’s kind of surprising to experience some sudden freezes. No Dedicated Servers – I always have a hard time trying to figure out how to connect to other players directly, and sometimes my network just doesn’t allow me to. There won’t be any servers hosted by Steam here, so players are pretty much on their own.Level Scaling – I can’t point my finger whether it is slow or it is just darn too fast. I haven’t been far from the spawn location and I already found a higher level item, now imagine what else could happen if I continue. And I’m personally having a hard time killing monsters which are supposed to be a piece of cake since it is still near the spawn location.

												This game is decent, It is fairly cheep, and I throughly am enjoying it. This game provides some new elements that I think lacked in terrari (139 hours on terraria as of now) While this game is a terraria clone and I don't recomend it to you if 1.) you dislike terraria, or 2.) havent played terraria, I personally thought it was a great new game to play, rather than terraria. content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Crea is an excellent game. I recommend it to anyone who is looking to play a fluid, expansive 2D sandbox universe. My favourite aspect of Crea is the crafting and skills. Not only can you upgrade equipment to have major bonuses against monsters, but you can create immersive little hovels to put all your stuff in. It's honestly the quaintest little game i've ever played.There isn't much wrong with Crea. I would suggest doing a few playthroughs if you are new to the genre, as it can be somewhat difficult at first. Once you get the hang of it, it's a fun experience that is more relaxing than anything else. I don't know what the developers plan to add in future updates, but I would like to see more immersive armors and weapons, maybe even some low-level rings and accessories. Making them accessable by level 18+ might make the gameplay a little smoother, but I personally enjoy the grind. An example of other weapons and armors would be staves and a variety of robes (can you tell I play a mage character?). The only thing that bothers (slightly) me about Crea is the placement of physical power weapons on the characters. I mean literally how far they appear to jut from my hands. I think they are a little too far out. Some of the weapons even feel over-sized, but that might just be me.Overall, an excellent game. 11/10

content:

Early Access Review
								Similar to Starbound and Terraria, while still remaining unique and interesting. Crea focuses more on the traditional sense in it being an RPG. Levels, skills, and magic!


YouTube™ Video: Crea - Mac Gameplay 

			Views: 1,217		

			NEW Crea is out now on Mac! A 2D sandbox RPG with magic, and adorable skull wearing slime monsters Click Here To Subscribe  http://bit.ly/19ksM1a Website  http://www.alvalentyn.co Crea - Steam ...		

 Leveling up is similar in respects to The Elder Scrolls games, where practice makes perfect. So if you want to spend an entire day just mining and leveling up that gathering skill, you sure can.  Crea's crafting system  also has yet another divergance from it's Starbound and Terraria siblings, in that you actively need to use resources and materials for research. Simply having some stone and wood doesn't mean you can make an axe. You have to use the Research Table, and actually figure out how. Consuming the materials in the process however. The game might start off slow, but once you get into the swing of things is extremely fun. Combat and controls are exciting and responsive, in a somewhat 2D-platformer way, and thanks to the unique and character progression, and environments, with a sprinkle of formidable random world bosses means there's hours of fun to be had.Overall the game is extremely fun, and I prefer it over Starbound simply down to it's old school RPG elements,

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really enjoy this genre, and think Crea is a good addition to it. I'm excited to see what mods people create, and maybe even for contributing one myself.The music is excellent, the graphics are good, and I sort of like the slightly different control mechanic. I find some others in the genre a little clunky and didn't have that experience with Crea.So, while it's good, I had to mod some things for it to be playable for me. The rate of collection from the beginning is slow, which is fine, but I also have a day job and wasn't enjoying the grind -- this is a pretty simple thing to fix, and there's a mod tutorial that will give you enough information to modify the tool you're using to make it faster (the tutorial is for windows, and I'm on a mac). If it seems like I'm complaining, I'm not, because I had the power to change it to my liking, which is really the idea. Though, it might be nice to have this be a world setup configuration for those that don't want to jump into modding?I appreciate the concept behind the research, and think it's a good idea. I would appreciate seeing a research tree, or at least some indication of progression though. I have researched all the materials I've found (there's an indication bar for each material, and it seems like when it's full/yellow you've researched it as much as is possible), but I don't really know if there's more materials or anything, which makes it sort of feel like more of a hinderance than an advancement. I really can't say if I have researched all of the craftables or not -- is there more? Not sure what my feedback is about making that feel more explorative and less restrictive though.That's pretty much it for my feedback. It's a fun play, and it feels pretty wide open for cool mods -- if you know python, get in there and start CREAting.

Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016 Review I recently started playing this game honestly not knowing what to expect, so I sat down and played it.  And it turns out theres more to this game than meets the eye.  Crea is a side scroller RPG/Crafing game that has a little of everything.The game play took a little getting used to for me. I will be honest I havent played a side scroller since the early 90's.  But, this game showed theres more to it.  From massive exploration to classic feeling boss fights, this game combines a bunch of elements to keep players entertained time and time again.  While the crafting system is a tad confusing and may need a rework, the combat is fun.  Also in the game is a great multiplayer functionality where you and your friends can team up to survive and take down the bosses and earn those heartwarming achievements together.Whats nice about this game is it seems to be extremely community driven.  Players can always leave suggestions and bug reports on the discussion forums, or even go to twitch where the developer can be seen and chat with directly.  Rating: 6/10 Pros:  Leveling system that levels up an area dependant on a task, such as crafting or exploration Being able to craft entire homes with furniture for more of that homely feelMultiplayer, so you dont have to survive the world alone  A very active developer and constant updates Cons:  Crafting system seems to be overly complex making the game feel a little frustratingI have noticed that if your playing with people and they make a large above ground structure...you might not be going that directionTutorial extremely lackingSome map seeds become extremely hard to navigate causing you to spend more time building land bridges just to get resources. 												The trailer makes it seem like a  reskin of Starbound, but it's really not . The game progression is much more fluid in comparson. The RPG aspect of leveling up to gain points which can be put into stats and building a talent tree to gain specific skills meshes so well with the existing concept of exploring a vast world to find materials, weapons, and gear to better yourself.This game is oozing with potential, but potential is meaningless if it goes to waste . I can see this being wicked fun to play with friends. The idea of grouping up with a warrior, an archer, a mage, and a healer to take on a crazy tough boss seems so exciting, but the path to that fight is pretty bare bones. It is excusable because it's early-access, but there's gotta be more content. I only hope the devs refine this possible gem with their hard work.Tl;DrGame is good. Leveling and skills/talent development works well with Terraria styled adventure game. Needs more content.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
												---I received this game from the developer in order to review it. You will get my honest feelings about the game (both good and bad).---Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016ReviewFor review purposes, most of my playing time took place just before and just after the game came out of early access (around Version 1.0.0) Also I used a keyboard and mouse to play.Crea is a Sandbox game with RPG and Crafting elements. When you first start the game you get a sword, shield and a mining tool and that is pretty much it. From there you need to fight, explore and scavenge your way through the game, mining elements and creating items with recipes you unlock during play. The game really is quite in depth and takes quite a bit of time to get used to. I feel like after 18 hours of play, I have barely scratched the surface of what is offered in this game. There are 3 equipment slots and 3 accessory slots on top of weapon and shield slots. As your character levels up you can level up 8 different stats and on top of that there are 5 subsections (Arms, Syle, Gather, Craft and Explore). Each of these subsections have their own level and points awarded for reaching certain criteria and there are between 10 and 20 different spells and abilities to unlock using these points for each subsection. The game really is quite in depth and again I feel like I have only scratched the surface.Crea really is a great Sandbox game with a huge amount to discover. Hopefully if things continue in a positive direction, it will easily leave its competition in the dust. In the following section, I will go into a bit about what makes this game great and a few things it needs to improve on.Rating:8.5/10Pros:Replay Factor : Their are many reasons to keep coming back to this game. I have been playing for close to 20 hours and Im sure I have barely touched the surface of this game. With so many ways to upgrade different stats and objects, you will keep coming back every chance you get. Steam Workshop support included provides players the opportunity to really make this game their own.4-Pack : Being able to purchase the game in a 4-Pack is great as this game really should be played with friends. I started out by playing on a server with a group but I quickly had to switch to single player when the server wasn't kept up to date. I will explain about this further below.Developer Involvement : The developer really has listened to the community to this point. I wasn't able to play much multiplayer because with every game update the server needed to be reset and the person running the server couldn't keep up with all the updates being released. It just seemed like every time someone ran into an issue, it was corrected almost as soon as it was reported. It is hard to find dedication like that.Game Play : Everything from the mining and crafting to the fighting of mobs seemed quite smooth. There does seem to be a bit of lag that I encountered just before I wrote the review but I understand the developer knows about it and I can only imagine it will be fixed any time now with the next update! Overall though a very smooth and easy to play game.Achievements and Trading Cards : Although these were not implemented until around the time of the games full release, they are now available and working as they should be. These are by no means a necessity but always a great addition as many people love their cards and achievements.Cons:No Dedicated Server : For a game like this I would expect a dedicated server to be available as the game really lends itself to play with friends. As you can see in the pros above, 4-Packs are available and you could have one of your friends try to set up and run their own server but I really feel a dedicated server is needed here. Not sure if there are plans to implement this or not at this point.Tutorial : There is a tutorial in the game but it seems like there isn't much info to get enough of an idea what you need to do or how to progress. The one thing I will point out is that there is a Crea Wiki page (Not sure about links but you can Google it to find where it is) I tried to stay away from it as I wanted to play the game without getting any hints but if you run into trouble I'd suggest starting there.Slow Start : I found the game quite slow at the start. I don't know if it was because I wasn't able to craft the right gear early enough but I really didn't get any good gear until level 15 but after that things really took off. This may have to do with the tutorial not being as deep as I feel it should have though.Disclaimer:Source of consideration: Siege Games

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Tuesday, June 14th, 2016 Review 32 hours and counting... that is how long i have played this game. it now ranks in my top .5%(yes, I do mean one half of one percent) of games on steam ranked by hours played. Suffice to say, I have enjoyed it very much, and this is considering I had my doubts that I would get into this game at all going in. Anyway, lets get into it. You all know the buzzwords by now: sandbox, rpg, survival, crafting etc, and that is all well and good, but I would like to talk about exactly what compels me to come back to this game time and time again. I think it comes down to the fact that there is always something different that I am excited to do next. There is usually at least one skill that I am excited to level up. The leveling system is packed with options. Your character as a whole will level up, in addition to acquiring skill points in different categories including syle(magic), crafting, exploring and more. Each category is loaded with different skills to learn. Each set of skills has its own method for accumulating points to buy the skills. Combat consists of both physical and magic attacks, along with a set of skills for each. The fighting itself feels right. You have hand to hand and ranged weapons, as well as a variety of spells at your disposal. Monsters are scattered throughout the land, and you will also be able to enter dungeons that exist outside of the world. I particularly enjoy that each dungeon comes with a specific set of rules. A dungeon may have invisible creatures and no healing allowed, for example. The dungeons can be found in the wild, but you can also craft a NPC who will allow you to jump right into a dungeon that you can create to your specifications. The dungeons keep things fresh with their changes from one to the next. Exploration is also a great way to spend time. I spent much of my time wandering around taking in all the sights and collecting new items. There are various biomes above ground, and an immense world of caverns and secrets when you venture underground. Hours upon hours can be spent exploring any given world. I must say that the one downside of the randomly generated worlds would be that you may have a tough time finding certain items. In my case, There were a few items the game expected me to acquire around the time when my character reached level 10, but due to the random nature of the world, the biome that contains them ended up being far, far away from me. I made it to level 20 or so before I found I had no choice but to venture out to retrieve the items. Unfortunately, the creatures there were all level 40 and could crush me in a single hit. I am willing to accept this task as a chance occurance, but it did slow my progress in the game. The crafting system is based on recipes. I would go out exploring, and each time I returned, I would run over and see what new item recipes i could uncover with the items I had gathered on my journey. New uses for items will become available as you level up, so there was always a chance that some old random item would suddenly become very useful again. There is also a system that involves chaos. It adds a unique twist where you try to improve the quality of your items before the chaos gets too high. It certainly helps to differentiate the crafting system from other games, but may be a bit confusing for beginners. In the end, everything is done well. That is what makes crea so great. I can set off to mine for some ore, only to have it turn into a great adventure into a dungeon that gives me some key items to open up a new pile of goods to craft. I love that the possibilities seem endless everytime I leave my home base and set out into the world. Nothing seems like a chore, and the next epic discovery may be waiting right around the corner.Rating: 8.7/10 Pros:  Dev is super active. He is literally on twitch everyday fixing bugs and chatting. This is one of those games where there is always just one more thing that I want to do before I quit.  Cons:  Crafting can be confusing for beginners, particularly the chaos aspect. Randomly generated worlds can cause problems gathering certain items if you run into bad luck during world creation. Beginners should stay close to the starting point until they get stronger. It can be tough to resist the urge to wander further to explore. Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege Games

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
Product received for free
Should You Buy This Game?Crea is a procedurally generated 2D sandbox RPG. The gameplay focuses on collecting/harvesting material and environmental objects/enemies in order to craft items, learn recipes and level up talents. The large and expansive world (if you choose to create such a world) includes multiple terrain/biomes, dungeons, creatures and objects. The world is fairly dense, and a day/night cycle creates a truly immersive setting. Crea is definitely recommended to those that are fans of the 2D sandbox RPG genre (there really aren’t that many on Steam). For everyone else, I would advise waiting for a deeper sale, or go in with a few buddies on a 4-pack (individually cheaper this way). Online multiplayer is supported.First Impressions----06/10/2016----Character & CombatWhen you first make a character (after creating a “small/medium/large” world), you will then be left to proceed at your own pace. Equipped with two modes, Combat & Build, your character will often be switching between the two in order to harvest in peace. The Combat system utilizes a customizable two handed approach, along with a jump and roll-dodge mechanic. A health and stamina bar will limit your prowess. Talent SystemTalents, or skills, are categorized under Arms, Syle (Magic), Gather, Craft, and Explore. Each talent must be unlocked by reaching a certain level, then purchasing with the pre-requisite amount of TP (talent points) – earned by performing actions from that particular category. Some of the skills include: Ledge Grab, Refine, Tool Proficiency, Fireball, Dash etc.EquipmentCharacters may be equipped with a Helm, Chest and Leg armors, along with 3 accessories (disregarding Combat/Build equipment). The character is progressed through an XP level system, and the stats that can be modified are: Health, Stamina, Attack, Defense, Intelligence, Mind, Agility, and Luck.CraftingThere is a plethora of crafting categories and sub-categories that include armor, furniture, outfits, recipes, tools etc. Not all crafting objects/recipes are learned at start. Research must be performed, which generally occurs in the form of retrieving a new item and interacting with the Research Desk.Current State of the GameDeveloper SupportAs of this review, the developers have fixed multitudes of minor bugs and a few major bugs reported by users through Steam reviews and from their website/forums. Originally in Early Access, the official release was launched during this review process. When referring to the Steam News or Discussions board, you can see very active involvement from the developers. I once saw a thread about a door glitch, and the developer responded and fixed the bug within 3 hours of the thread’s posting. The biggest takeaway points are listed below:Highlights:Diverse sceneryDay/night cycleLarge/procedurally generated worldsDungeonsObstacles:Starting inventory space is too smallControllers are supported, but extremely tedious to use (having to aim reticle in order to harvest with a controller is a bit cumbersome)UI is a bit lacking; quantities of which items are possessed/needed for a recipe is a bit confusing to interpret due to absent labels.DisclaimerA copy of this game was provided by the developer: Siege Games; however, this did not bias my review in any form.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updated (8/29/'15) Making yet another edit to this game. I recently just started playing again as of two days ago, reason being I've been busy most of the time, With little time left to seriosly play this game. What I am really a fan of is Crea's combat system. You can actually use your shield to block and you can somewhat dodge things, it's not just  *click* *click* *skill* and there is a lot of different ways to mix up the combat to have a continuiously fun time. What I mostly spend my time in Crea doing is Exploring, and crafting. Even with 300 hours on the game I can definitely say There's a lot I really haven't done, due to the fact I've been just exploring the world. There's so much to see and discover. Exploring is fun, yes, and it's not completely useless. you actually do NEED to explore, you won't be able to find your materials all in one place. You have to go far and wide to find the things you need.With crafting there's a ton of things to do with this. Before, (which I thought was more fun) You had to actually go around and kill stuff, and use the items you find to put towards a crafting recipe in order to find out how to make the item. So you'd need to find the materials one by one until you finally get the right combination. That's also something I've had fun doing. Now, it's a bit more easier and i'm not complaining, it gives me time to do more in Crea.Lastly, the modding is something I have great hopes in. There are already some creations on the workshop, but I would like to see a lot more.  This is the game where I definitely want to try to sink my feet into with modding the game. I also would like to see a lot more people play this game, but that's going to come sooner or later. With Crea, there's really an exciting future in store for all of us fans. I highly recommend it.~Prinny

content:
Posted: February 17
												[UPDATE]So Jasson released a update and the game is working beautifully. There are some fps dips on game start but it WILL go away! The gui has been reworked and works wonderfully! To some older players who have a game crash on launch just unsub some/all of the mods for the game and it should run.The game at times can feel like a grind but in my personal opinion it is not a "bad" kind of grind. It is quite rewarding and makes you want to put in the hours to get somewhere. The talent system is awesome and while I do feel that more talents should be added I also feel that it is not necessary just yet. This is due to the fact that there is a lot of different talents and trust me it will take a while to get them all.I have noticed that at first it may feel the enemies are OP to some but you can block, dodge or later on cast protection spells + healing spells,potions or food which will benefit you in a fight.Honestly after the most recent update I can full on recommend this to anyone. The devs are constantly communicating and their attitudes are great so all in all you can expect things to be fixed if something goes wrong.If you love 2D adventure games with magic and beautiful art + music and mod support then you should for sure try Crea.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early days yet, but Crea still impresses.Although this game is early access, it is more than playable. The crafting/research system is excellent, pacing the development of characters well, giving purpose to seeking out and harvesting even basic minerals. The idea of using pre-crafted items as part of recipes, almost like upgrades, also keeps a good progressive pace.Although there is only one boss at present, the game itself is extensive and exploration can go on for hours.The easy 'moddability' of Crea is a surprisingly strong point. Within mere minutes, it is possible to create additional in game items from weapons to furniture.Visually pleasing however the scaling of the screen resolution can be an issue. There is a scaling slider in options, but this can be buggy at times.I would recommend this game for fans of the 2D Sandbox genre or crafting/survival games in general.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								A unique name for a game, but sometimes it's the hidden gem behind a name that truly stands out. Crea is very much like Starbound; crafting items and weapons/armor and battling baddies. Some major differences from Starbound is that you level up when you earn enough XP, and each weapon/tool that is used will grant you the XP tied to a particular category. Kind of like a crafting survival RPG. You're always full--hunger is exempt here. The graphics aren't anything special, but if you enjoyed playing SB's pixel graphics you'll likely approach Crea in a positive way. I've experienced some lag while playing, and this is for single-player. It's very minor, fortunately. The soundtrack's pretty soothing until it abruptly ends for an odd reason; I still find SB's unbeatable, though. Busy with Starbound so why did I buy Crea? It's indie developed and Python was used to make it--I've been learning Python since last year on my spare time, and I want to be able to see the code and learn from it. Modding is available too.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I would give this game a solid 4/5, which is amazing considering it was just released. Between the levelling system, crafting, skills, and world exploration, this is a must-buy.As far as critiques go, I would say that the skill levelling needs to be tweaked a bit. It is very rare that your crafting level and your player level coincide, resulting in you not being able to use the armor/weapons that you can make or not being able to make the armor/weapons that you need. This takes away a lot of the game's momentum, as it results in you needing to grind crafting recipes or monsters before you can continue to progress. Also, with the crafting system, it's nice that you can pay scrap to learn a recipe if you just can't figure out a couple of the ingredients, but this system would work a lot better if you could just pay 50 scrap to uncover each individual part of a recipe. Also there needs to be a more reliable way to get scrap; the scrapper machine (or whatever it's called) gives like 1 scrap for every 5 or so good items you destroy (totally not worth it).Also, I may be missing something, but it's really hard to use combat skills in combat. If you wanted to use more than 4 combat skills (plus heal), you're basically SOL since your toolbar is full. a toolbar with more slots would help alleviate this problem. Aside from these trivial critiques, the fact remains that this a superb game. More immersive than Terraria and more fun than Edge of Space or even Dig or Die. Buy it while it's on sale!

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Was looking for a game like Terraria after being disappointed by Starbound. This game adds an RPG and a research dynamic that are a lot of fun, and helps with the feeling of progression. The varioius spells in the game add more unique ways of killing enemies as well. I am not really into the "base building" and I just buid the essentials(no decorations), so I cannot comment a lot on that aspect of the game, but I have no complaints about it either. If I did have any compliants about this game they would be: 1. The spells do not have very much information, so it is hard to tell how much stronger the next level is. It may be based on level, but that would be useful information as well. Also, they only go up to level 5, which is easy to get to. 2. I feel the underground is very dark, even with a lot of torches, so sometimes it is hard to see. 3. It would be nice to be able to tell what items you could make from materials, by clicking on them in the "materials" list. As of now, I have trouble organizing garbage materials from the good ones(like I said I dont care about decoration items)Overall I am glad I picked this game up! I have been having a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016 Review Crea is Siege Games take on the terraria/starbound sandbox kind of game with some really interesting ideas and mechanics. Most notable would be the inclusion a large variety of skills and talents, You gain experience for levels and to spend on talents like mining, fighting, exploring and crafting. Learning recipes is interesting as you need to research different materials that you find to begin unlocking them. The graphics are nice enough, if a little small on my big monitor. The music is pleasant and doesnt seem to get too repetitive. It has nice multiplayer and I only noticed a few bugs. I have played a few hours(several offline), researched a lot of recipes, explored several caves, died countless times to creatures simple and complex alike. This is definitely a game worth sinking time into! Rating: 8.0/10 Pros:  Combat - Blocking, using skills, very fun and an interesting addition to this style of game. Research - Hording all those materials is worthwhile! You might learn some really nice recipes :) Talents - Grants abilities to help with everything. Crafting can be improved, you can even learn to grab the edge of a ledge. Mini Dungeons - When you kill a creature spawner, there seems a chance to drop a crystal, and if you use it, you teleport to a small dungeon of those spawners, and you have to kill them all to get treasures. Mode Switch - Switch between combat hotbar and building hotbar with the press of a button.  Cons:  Day/Night Cycle - It seems a bit fast, before I know it, it is dark again. Lighting - Could just be me, as I havent gotten very far, but I cant seem to light the place up enough  Hardware Information   Hardware Type   Monitor LG-27MP37HQ-27 IPS Monitor   Headphones Razer Adaro Wireless   Keyboard Razer Deathstalker   Controller Logitech F310   Mouse Logitech M-U0028   Microphone Microphone   Motherboard MS-7693   CPU AMD FX-6300   GPU AMD Radeon R9 380   RAM 8GB   OS Windows 10   HDD HDD  Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege Games

Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016 Review Crea is an RPG/sandbox hybrid game, in the style of Terarria. Despite being 2D side-scroller, the Creas procedural generated worlds are vast and beautifully rendered, making it all to easy to put hours and hours into the crafting of your world and levelling of your characters. While the tutorial is brief, the learning curve is not to steep - I found it took a while for the game to pick up pace. Once you get there though there is an enjoyably detailed RPG adventure with many talents and skills to master. Rating: 7.0/10 Pros:  Vast game to explore with procedurally generated worlds Good mod support Fast travel avoids potential tedium Well built levelling system  Cons:  Combat with spells a little clunky User interface a little tough to use/reead Game takes a while to pick up pace  Hardware Information   Hardware Type   Monitor BenQ GW2760 1920x1080   Headphones Logitech Wireless Gaming Headset G930   Keyboard Gamdias HERMES Lite Mechanical Keyboard   Controller Xbox 360 Controller for Windows   Mouse Sharkoon Fireglider   Microphone Logitech Wireless Gaming Headset G930   Motherboard msi sli x99 plus   CPU Intel i7 5820k   GPU GeForce GTX 980   RAM 16GB   OS Windows 7   HDD 256GB SSD + 2 x 1TB HDD + 1 x 8TB NAS  Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege Games

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016 Review Crea is a is a side scrolling 2d open world sandbox game where you obtain materials by hacking up the rocks, trees and creatures around you and craft items. There is also lore items you can find. The game starts you out alone in the wilds but there is a tutorial that does a nice job of telling you what there is to do and how to go about doing it. Other similar games have left me a bit lost so this was very welcome. You can also re-open the tutorial so review anything you may have forgotten. I also enjoyed the talent system which just by doing something I earned talent points and spent these points on skills. This gave a nice feeling of character growth and progression. While I only played the single player version I found the game to be fun to play and pleasing visually and audibly. Rating: 6.5/10 Pros:  Tutorial was helpful and I was able to refer back to it. Graphics and sound effects were simple but pleasing. The backgrounds were really pretty. Ability to alternate between build and combat mode as a toggle made less confusing UI. A wide variety of monsters to slaughter. Some were so cute I felt bad killing them. Difficulty settings let me play on easy till I figured out what I was doing.  Cons:  I died super easy. I dont know if I am just bad but its frustrating to die to your first slime. I would like to choose what displays to the General and Battle tabs. The music, which is really good, does not play often enough. I interacted with a realm crystal but I have no idea what it did. It did transport me somewhere else. I leveled up but never saw a tutorial about it. content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												I think this game falls under a "wait and see" category, even though I did mark this as a recommended review. I decided on this because while there are notable flaws, my overall experience wasn't negative and the developer seems to be constantly working on the game. I picked Crea up during its -10% release sale. The developer has said the next sale will be in December 2016, at ~25% off.I suppose the first game people jump to in comparison is Terraria. I loved Terraria. I rarely think about Terraria when playing this game. I would draw more similarities to Starbound. I didn’t like Starbound, but Crea doesn’t draw out the same dullness I felt from there. Crea has two leveling systems. The first is the general character/combat level that increases as you kill monsters. Your stats go up, you get a point to allocate, simple enough. The second is the Talent system. Whenever you take an action, you have a chance to gain experience in a corresponding Talent, Arms (Weapons), Syle (Magic), Gather, Craft, and Explore. It’s a very nice system that feels rewarding… aside from Craft. I’ll talk about that later.Graphics are nice, I like the more subtle colors compared to Terraria, while still remaining crisper than Starbound. Music is nice and accompanies the slower gameplay very well. Even though the gameplay is slower, I never really felt like my character itself was too slow. I know in Terraria the initial startup movement is extremely painful, but it feels good in Crea. Even with a Sprinting talent unlocked, I often forget about it simply because the normal walking speed is a great pace. The time before a grappler can be obtained is smoothed out with a Ledge Grab talent, and you can unlock a Double Jump talent farther in. Way Crystals are sprinkled throughout the world, and you can harvest them and create your own. You can choose any Way Crystal as your spawn point and teleport back using warp crystals that grow around Way Crystals. These grow back in pretty large numbers, so you’re never really low on them.Now, Craft… it just feels bad after a certain point. At first, you’re blowing through it like every other talent. And then it stops. Why? Because you’ve already crafted what you needed. So you’ll find yourself running around, have all your other Talents continue going up in level… while the game is waiting for you to grind Craft. And it’s not supposed to be just random junk either. Nope. You have to craft things close to your level to actually gain exp. And only sometimes, because gaining Talent exp is through chance. Now, I will say I can’t tell if there’s a level indicator on non-level-restricted items, and I’ve seen some mentions about candle crafting working (which is somewhat cheap), but the whole idea just feels very contrasting with the other talents. It’s usually huge spikes in research followed by large droughts, you have to actively work on it with some vague concepts, while all the other Talents just happen, and it feels tightly linked to progression.Overall, though, if you happen to look up Craft help and get through it’s not horrible. Crea has potential. Multiplayer needs to be ironed out but singleplayer seems fun.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I would give this game a solid 4/5, which is amazing considering it was just released. Between the levelling system, crafting, skills, and world exploration, this is a must-buy.As far as critiques go, I would say that the skill levelling needs to be tweaked a bit. It is very rare that your crafting level and your player level coincide, resulting in you not being able to use the armor/weapons that you can make or not being able to make the armor/weapons that you need. This takes away a lot of the game's momentum, as it results in you needing to grind crafting recipes or monsters before you can continue to progress. Also, with the crafting system, it's nice that you can pay scrap to learn a recipe if you just can't figure out a couple of the ingredients, but this system would work a lot better if you could just pay 50 scrap to uncover each individual part of a recipe. Also there needs to be a more reliable way to get scrap; the scrapper machine (or whatever it's called) gives like 1 scrap for every 5 or so good items you destroy (totally not worth it).Also, I may be missing something, but it's really hard to use combat skills in combat. If you wanted to use more than 4 combat skills (plus heal), you're basically SOL since your toolbar is full. a toolbar with more slots would help alleviate this problem. Aside from these trivial critiques, the fact remains that this a superb game. More immersive than Terraria and more fun than Edge of Space or even Dig or Die. Buy it while it's on sale!

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								A unique name for a game, but sometimes it's the hidden gem behind a name that truly stands out. Crea is very much like Starbound; crafting items and weapons/armor and battling baddies. Some major differences from Starbound is that you level up when you earn enough XP, and each weapon/tool that is used will grant you the XP tied to a particular category. Kind of like a crafting survival RPG. You're always full--hunger is exempt here. The graphics aren't anything special, but if you enjoyed playing SB's pixel graphics you'll likely approach Crea in a positive way. I've experienced some lag while playing, and this is for single-player. It's very minor, fortunately. The soundtrack's pretty soothing until it abruptly ends for an odd reason; I still find SB's unbeatable, though. Busy with Starbound so why did I buy Crea? It's indie developed and Python was used to make it--I've been learning Python since last year on my spare time, and I want to be able to see the code and learn from it. Modding is available too.

								Was looking for a game like Terraria after being disappointed by Starbound. This game adds an RPG and a research dynamic that are a lot of fun, and helps with the feeling of progression. The varioius spells in the game add more unique ways of killing enemies as well. I am not really into the "base building" and I just buid the essentials(no decorations), so I cannot comment a lot on that aspect of the game, but I have no complaints about it either. If I did have any compliants about this game they would be: 1. The spells do not have very much information, so it is hard to tell how much stronger the next level is. It may be based on level, but that would be useful information as well. Also, they only go up to level 5, which is easy to get to. 2. I feel the underground is very dark, even with a lot of torches, so sometimes it is hard to see. 3. It would be nice to be able to tell what items you could make from materials, by clicking on them in the "materials" list. As of now, I have trouble organizing garbage materials from the good ones(like I said I dont care about decoration items)Overall I am glad I picked this game up! I have been having a lot of fun.
