content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well i've only played Crea for 90 minutes at this point, and what I think is this is a great game with alot of potential. The game feels a lot more relaxed than others of the genre, but that's also it's worst point. I know this is Early Access and alot is going to change, but in it's current state it's just kind of...barren. Within the time I played I have yet to build anything simply because there is no point, there is no threat. You can dig underground where monsters don't spawn and you're safe, why waste material on something that isn't needed?Now for for the best bit of the game, it is just so easy to get into. Unlike Terraria (which is just too clustered with content) and Edge of Space (which is a fairly complex game) it has a decent amount of content which isn't a massive overload. The best thing is, I think it will stay that way. I believe there will be (alot) more content in the final release, but not over done due to the fact it plans on using Steam Workshop. I love the idea of openly being invited to change and adapt the game to suit my needs with either community content or self made content. Why go all out adding alot of optional things that is just going to make it cluttered, right? Combat is a nice change too. You can assign items, weapons and spells to the hotbar, and then assign each one to either LMB or RMB. For example I use my trusty sword (LMB) and a good ol' fireball (RMB) which is assigned to hotbar box 1, where as I could assign a pickaxe and torches to 2 and so on. This mean alot less pesky fiddling with inventory or scrolling hotbar constantly. Spells are also one of the best bits of combat, i'm not much for a mage character but feel myself wanting to use my spells more than anything else. The problem with combat at this stage is that enemies level up with you. It's a good idea, but because everything is as strong as you, you don't feel any threat of dying or wanting to stay away from certain enemies. It's just a case of "well I can kill most of these easy". I'd like the enemies to be a preset level, so different biomes have a higher/lower threat than others. The same with underground exploring, enemies should spawn more frequently the further down you go.Finally the leveling system. I have found no fault in this so far. There are 5 categroies; Combat (Melee and Ranged combat), Gathering (as you'd think, picking up harvested blocks and items), Crafting (crafting items), Magic (using damage based spells) and Restoration (not sure that's the right name, but basically spells like healing). You don't get general experience and choose where to put in skills point, for each thing you do (kill an enemy with a sword and craft a new helmet) you get TP in that set category. This is great, why would you learn more about crafting if you killed something? I like the way it's done, I kill and I get TP in combat, I pick up some logs and I get TP in gathering. You don't need to level up to put points in a skill either (though certain skills are unlocked at higher levels), for example I can learn a new spell for 1000 TP in the magic category. This doesn't stunt level progression either, it's about amount of TP gained in total rather than how much you already have.All in all a good game, I can't wait for the finished product. I think it'll be the one of the best in the genre ( though Terraria is hard to beat)A solid 8/10

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
Product received for free
												I had no big expectations from Crea and thought it would be yet another one of these new uninspired games trying to jump on the bandwagon of the sandbox genre. After playing it for five minutes, I knew how wrong I was. Those 5 minutes suddenly turned into 3 hours and I had to make myself stop as it was already 2 A.M. It could be argued that Crea looks exactly like other similar games, and although that might be true, Crea knows how to combine ideas that we have all already seen in other games with a lot of new ones, creating a perfect mix with hours and hours of entertainment and freedom. It contains not only the tools to set free your creativity, but also a concealed complex game with its own lore. You can choose to ignore it completely, or you can try to delve deeper. This certainly translates to many hours and many different possible approaches to the same game. It’s, simply put, a 2D Minecraft. Although as complex as Notch’s game, Crea helps its players and guides them through the game, making external online searches unnecessary, something I must really thank the developers for. I have not found too many negative things, but I believe more sounds are needed (for example for enemies), more game modes (creative or permadeath), weather effects and a bit of enemy balancing (if you explore too much, you suddenly encounter very high-leveled enemies) Otherwise, I honestly could not ask for more, as the game is awesome as it is.  In my opinion, this game receives a score of 9 out of 10. Once more mods are created and those game modes are implemented, this game will become the ultimate 2D alternative to Minecraft. Pros:- Fun and easy to put a ton of hours in- Awesome tools for creation- RPG elements perfectly implemented- Bits of lore and lore related features- Interesting achievements and cards- Mod implementation- Fair priceCons:- More sound effects would be nice- Weather effects missing (rain, snow, desert storms…) - More game modes would be a great additionI personally can’t wait until a hunger/thirst mod is created. I’d also like to address some of the problems other people have mentioned: It is true that the game takes long to load, but it isn’t longer than a minute and I’m used to waiting more than 5 minutes for Crusader Kings II to load. Once the game loads, you no longer have any kind of waiting time and everything is seamless.I’ve also noticed that the game opens like 5 different processes if you check using task manager. I’m not sure that’s the most efficient way for the game to run, but I have personally not experienced any kind of lag or bug in my 6 hours of gameplay so far and once you close the game, all those processes close along the game. I have a 6 year old crappy laptop, if that helps. If you are worried about the game, I encourage you to watch a few gameplays on youtube, which surely helps more than just reading reviews and then decide for yourself. Have fun!Disclaimer: I received this product for free from the Developer in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
Please, keep in mind that this is only an opinion of mine and each of us has their own, unique, thoughts. The review describes my expression of the game and nothing more than that. Moreover, this particularly review holds more formal nature and form. The review might be updated later to follow game's playing style and nature.April 4th, year 2016. The copy was obtained from Siege Games.What will you think being at Crea's storepage for the first time? "Oh, once again a sandboxy Terraria clone." But be sure that won't be precisely right. Of course, we can't deny there are similarities in both games as well as in the genre in general. That's why being a fan of lookalike titles you are always looking for something new and innovative to be in the forthcoming product. And truly, Crea possess some interesting elements and features which make it distinctive compared to its predecessors.Without further go, I really enjoyed Crea. It might look similar for the newcomers at the beginning as you are thrown into the world, given some instructions and set to go. However, the further you progress the deeper game immersion becomes. As usual, you gather materials, kill monsters, craft gear and build a home for yourself. Then you dive deeper or travel farther to explore new horizons repeating all that on a greater scale. Sounds familiar, indeed, but there is more to it than what is seen plainly on surface. The most developed and well designed part of game is crafting system. It's interesting, it's catchy and what's even more important it's complex. You can't just "I got the deer muscus now I can make an *Uber 2156 Annihilator Optimus Prime". Here you have to actually research each material figuring its specifications and how and where it can be used - and you will need to do that several times learning more and more of a particular item as your researching (crafting) level increases and so do your skills. Therefore great or just regular items can be created when you collect enough materials to both analyze and use them in the crafting process. Though sometimes you can find prepared recipes as well. There are only few stations each usable for certain categories of items. You can "improve" them by finding (mostly in random chests) different techpieces. What's absolutely worth mentioning is 'Chaos system' which allows you to craft better items giving them additional stats or special characteristics depending on how well you manage to keep the "Chaos" from ruining your work using different features and talents to do so (that's sort of hard to explain in the review but I hope main point is still comprehensible). Next, there is also an extended talents "tree" with different branches. You gain points by running around, killing monsters, shooting hadoukens fireballs, breaking blocks and crafting and then allocate them to affiliated sections thus learning new fighting techniques and new spells as well as improving yourself and your more pacific skills generally. There are quite enough of such abilities so you won't be bored and can always try playing a new style, like battlemage or rogue-archer. Finally, lets talk about the world you are in and its content. As usual, you can create several sizes where each will have ground, sky and underground levels with different biomes. You can travel only by foot or by crystal waypoints, unfortunately, but who knows if wings or transport will be added in the future updates - that would surely be nice. Monster are unique and each has its own style and combat pattern so as abilities while some may be challenging to face in the early stage. There aren't many monsters though, to be honest. Bosses prove to be even more tough and provide a necessary degree of "buttpain" if you don't master evasion or figure what is the right way to fight them. Exploration aspect is solid enough with many caves and hidden goodies underground like chests or rooms with pages about the preset or world's past. Rather doable element is fighting/gathering: you have to switch between 2 modes which also have two tabs each which might be confusing a bit to those who were previously playing games like Terraria, for instance. You will constantly need to switch to fighting if you are mining underground, but It's still somewhat versatile system in the end. In-game animations are well done and lovely (except for the jumping). Graphics is pretty common to the genre but still has some charm to it mostly due to beautiful and full-blooded arts, though backgrounds are rather simple. Effects are stylish and there is physics in place - shooting ball of earth may destroy a block or drop icicles from the ceiling which will damage enemies when fall, for example. Main game menu is simple too but that's not to be concerned of. Interface is fine but small improvements could still be added (for example, bigger fonts). Soundtrack is nice and plausible to hear.Technically, there is nothing to be concerned of. Game is out of Early Access and was granted almost bugless state. The only issues I had so far are two crashes which appeared during boss fights when game was acting a big laggish and light sphere (the one serving as light source) dissapearing after you travel via crystal or die and a couple of sound effects missing (harvesting plants and logs underground, for instance), but that's not critical mostly. Performance & optimization is great overally and game runs smoothly on both powerful, mid-end and "cozy" specs like Mac Air (well, nothing surprising as it's not really resourceful).What was enjoyable:  Interesting and beautiful world with much to exploreLore and book of hostile creatures, journal with notes which you can find worldwide - game has a storyComplex and deep crafting system with Chaos system letting you craft better itemsTalents "tree" with many active abilities of different sorts to try outChallenging enemies and bosses with unique combat patternsActive developers with constant updates, confidence that game won't be deserted for a whileMultiplayer, Steam integration including achievements and Cloud Saving What proves lacking:  Only English as a language - that's not critical but surely lowers the potential player base Tutorial should be slightly more  detailed in my opinion (at least about crafting system and Chaos)Interface might not be that convenient for some users (small fonts and icons)Biomes could be more distinctive with addition of richer flora, background and music perhaps (for example, mushroom one is only varied trees and grass)A bit controversial fighting/gathering system which may require some time to get accustomed toNPCs could be more alive and more or talk at least (currently those are just animated interactive statues)Not so many monsters, bosses, music compositions while accent was made on mechanics in general and crafting: game feels completed but may become null at some point without further addons _____________________________________________8 Flying Flamethrower Boars out of 10. Fun and enjoyable, exciting and catchy, challenging and tricky Terraria'esque sandbox game with lots of great improvements and additions towards the genre. 'D'aventure artificielle' by all means.

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												As you can probably, see, I've sunk over 100 hours into this game, over a wide variety of patches, changes and ideas. I've talked with the devs, found fun errors, created amazing things, and killed pretty much everything by blade, spear and bow.tldr; Crea is Dark Souls lore and exploration in an open world setting. Ambitious, awesome, and has many strands of progress.Crea is a good, different take on the Terraria style game the genre descends from. Instead of handholding, guides and mysterious landmarks, Crea has tasked you with exploring, investigating and noticing things. I stumbled into the first boss by crafting a Chaos Bed, and then using it. Maybe I should've expected a magical, cloning, nightmare boss, but holy hell was that a pulse pounding victory.Later, I check the other teleporter tabs and found a new boss I had not seen before, and proceeded to get my stuff kicked in until I found a strategy that worked and actually pulled it off. Was it easy? No. Was it fun? Mostly. Was it exciting? Yes. Like many things, the boss fights are taking a known value [Enemies, lava, water, fallling] and adapting a strategy. Instead of the Terraria style "Build your own" arena, Crea bosses come with an arena, or spawn in a fixed area where you determined they should be.The crafting game is both light and heavy, and is constantly getting refined. You can make a weapon out of the barest, meagerest supplies possible, or you can forge it from start to finish to be a high quality, polished work, and the quality of the item will reflect this. This is done through a satisfying mini-game, where you race the chaos level you're injecting your works with, it starts out hilariously easy, 25 quality to 100 chaos, but will happily jump up to 200 quality to 100 chaos, and ramp up the challenge to perfect as well.The game mechanics are crisp, polished and are really based on comitting to an action [without the imput delay of the PC Dark Sous games], and through planning, posititioning, properly levelled skills and the use of the dodge roll, I found myself going from a struggling meatbag to an acrobatic jerk who would dance through the enemies and loot their remains.Above all, Crea rewards determination. As you do a thing, you get skill points for it, which can make you better at that. Crafting begets cooler crafting techniques, weapon combat helps you combat harder, etc. Not innovate, but well paced and most skills either bring a brand of utility [healing spells, ranged attacks] or help you get better at storming the world [ extra jumps/jump height, grappling ledges, extra inventory slots.] And yes, determination means I wish the game could be faster, but I also feel a sense of attachment for the characters I create.Overall, Crea is a very good, lightly flawed game. The dev himself is a kind, generous person, who may have dropped the game a bit early, but he had high hopes and a great heart behind it, and I know he's going to keep slamming out updates, content and great gameplay.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Product received for free
												I quite enjoyed Crea, the game is very similar to Terraria, with some variations.  Crea has your character leveling up, spending skill points, wielding magic, etc. You level skills such as tool speed, attack boost, defense boost, tool reach, and more. The crafting system takes its own direction as well, using research to learn new recipes.  This system allows the game to feel like more than just a clone.  Is the addition of RPG elements enough to set Crea apart from the other games like this..  I'd certainly say yes, it's unique enough to offer the hardcore 2d sandbox gameplayer, while keeping all the core mechanics that make the genre fun.  Building, crafting, looking, exploring and killing,  can all be found in one neat package..  While Minecraft is the king of 3d sandbox games, the market for 2d sandbox games exploded, and has brought about many games of various quality, Crea isn't the first but it's one of the best. Game play Much like other games in the genre, Crea has no real purpose outside of the users own imagination, build yourself a mammoth base, stock up on the rarest of materials and gear, or explore the depths of the earth and see if you can find out what makes the world tick.  Outside of the mechanics that are present in other games, the newer elements such as leveling, and gaining skill points really sets the game apart.  The RPG elements are a breath of fresh air.   Pros RPG elements (leveling, skills, etc etc etc)The Modding Community is fairly impressive and getting betterFull controller support Great big worlds  cons quite a few bugs and glitchesTutorial could be a bit more involved, Combat could be tweaked a bit to be more inline with other games of this genre recommendation If you enjoy sand box games, using your imagination and exploring an amazingly fun world, Crea will be right up your alley.  So many positives about Crea, that the few negatives are greatly overshadowed.  I think if you enjoy other games in the 2d sandbox genre, you'll love this one as well.  It has loads of content, loads of mods, and will leave the gamer feeling engaged.  I highly recommend the game to any and all sandbox gameplayers..

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								UPDATE:over a year has passed and i finally checked out the progress. actually a lot has changed, many of the issues i spoke of have significantly changed and improved. UI is more accessible,  the game feels smoother and the different aspects of the game seem to interact with each other a lot better.  im going to edit the review and say yes, now i recommend the game! it's good to see devlopers actually developing the product :)there are still some questions open, and answers to be given to jesson, the dev that commented my review.1) story development: yes please! crea is still all about its own game mechanics - they have improved a lot but its all about filling progress bars. character development is very nice, but a little story behind it, maybe even quests and campaigns would motivate a lot more - plus it acts like a feedback when you improve levels and skills. 2) character development: yes please! you have a lot of mechanics already, especially for the huge crafting system. thats perfectly fine, the number of skills is vast. but the main characteristics (like agility, intelligence,...) do not feel like having a real impact on the way i play. more limitations and benefits might help, like minimum values for using certain items and skills. e.g.  a high-intelligence character not better in researching stuff than a dumb brute - a high strength character cant carry more than others - a high agility is not necessary for picking locks.3) NPCs and character interaction: the idea of building dummies and dressing them up to get a little company for the main character is a little creepy if you think about it, but works surprisingly well as a mechanic to build your environment. but, will there be other npcs? if so, will you be able to interact with them? will there be dialogue and choices even, especially if you implement stories, big and small? it would be a real asset and a unique feature compared to all the tarrarias, starbounds and the likes out there.former review:dear crea developers,unfortunately i cannot recommend this title - yet. As with many early acces titles this one has great potential but it feels a little like things grow over the your heads. i always missed deep rpg elements in similar games but i understand it's difficult to create a whole new terraria or starbound AND add a complete roleplaying system with character development and everything to it. so if it is too much at once, why not mod titles that already exist and really concentrate on your new ideas and things that are really important to you?anyway, this is just guessing and suggesting.here a few bullets i recommend to improve:- the gui is not very smooth. for character display this is not that important but the crafting and inventory menus need simplicity, clarification and coherence to be intuitive.    - the pace feels not right: combat, crafting, moving, mining etc mechanisms need to bebalanced with each other, "speedwise"Additionally for the price people are paying for the early access they would expect more frequent updates - not even necessarily regarding real development but at least a post about anyhting you are doing.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								At 11 hours in I am really enjoying this game.  I fell in love with Terraria a while back and was looking for something similar when I found Crea.  Just being similar to Terraria would have been enough for me to like this game too but Crea is actually so much more.Unlike Terraria, Crea has added RPG mechanics to the sandbox, exploring, fighting, gathering, crafting, building genre.  So by playing the game I gain experience which levels up my character.  With each level-up I get points I can use to increase my character's attributes.  I also get Talent points which I can use to add or upgrade a large set of potential Skills like new magic spells, enhancements to melee and defense, and skills used to explore, gather and craft.  So Crea allows for much greater character customization and growth.  At this point of Early Access it doesn't seem to have as many vanity and visual character customization options but those are less important to me than the options that actually do stuff.Crea also has a unique and creative visual style.  When I am playing I find myself appreciating the way things look more than I remember doing in Terraria.  It also has a great a sense of humour.  Some of the tool tips are very funny.  And the creatures and enemies look great too and can be very amusing and weird in an interesting way.Enemy fighting style is also diverse and interesting.  No cookie cutter AI here.  I think the player has more different kinds of options too so I would say that combat is more complex in Crea.  I haven't fought any of the bosses yet but the day to day mobs have been fun to go up against so far.In addition to the procedurally generated worlds that you create there are also Realms and dungeons that you can transport to for an additional challenge and added areas to explore.Crea has also been designed to be easier to mod so I am looking forward to creating my own mods and seeing what other players come up with in the Steam Workshop.I think that people who like Terraria will like Crea a lot too.  I also recommend Crea to players new to the genre.  I am having a lot of fun with it and can see getting many more hours of play from this game.Edited to add:  Make sure you upgrade to Ledge Grab when you can.  It is very useful.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
Review Written on Monday, June 6th, 2016 Review I've had quite a few experiences with open-sandbox games before, but none of them can compare to the experience I had with Crea. The game visually resembles a Terraria-styled world with a much higher emphasis on character progression and skill-building. If you haven't played Terraria, its a game that is involves lots of exploring, crafting, building and mining to create new gear, items, and decorations for you and your friends. While Crea incorporates all of the core elements of Terraria, it does so in a different way that allows the game to be unique (mining is primarily done at the surface, and combat is more in depth etc.) While the two games share many assets, I will say that Terraria focuses on exploration and that Crea is focused on the RPG elements. Crea has a very neat experience system that makes everything count. Every item looted, attack used, or ore mined will increase your characters talent in that profession, allowing for upgrades that can be unlocked. This is great because it allows for player to choose how they want to upgrade their character, focusing on ranged or melee combat, or becoming a healing character. It makes the player feel more invested to build their character for online play, and makes mundane tasks feel more rewarding. The combat in the game is made much more advanced by giving the enemies levels to match the player, and when combined with the endless amount of crafting recipes, there's always another reason to improve your characters gear and stats. Rating: 8.4/10 Pros:  EXP system keeps the game going, even when it gets slow. Graphics look nice with lots of details. Takes all of the pros of Terraria, while keeping original.  Cons:   Game may require a wiki to get the best enjoyment. content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												I have about 38 hours in this game, and my experience has been mixed but generally favorable.The game is plagued by bugs and instability, and the art and lore can feel awkward and rushed.  Balance and progression are a bit wonky, and controller support is functional but problematic in some situations.  Often, it is not clear what you need to do to progress, and the game gives you no hints.  In fact, there are points at which you may not realize there is anything left to do at all, and it is easy to find oneself wondering, "Is this really all there is?"  For example, the mannequins in the game have an item description that says they are for displaying armor and outfits.  In truth, placing an outfit on a placed mannequin causes it to come to life, and it is the only way to encounter an NPC.  Some of the mechanics also feel forced and tiresome, such as the novel crafting system.Do I sound like I hate the game?  Great.  Nothing could be further from the truth.For all its flaws, this game has the crucial, undefinable ingredient that Terraria clones to date have lacked: a soul.  Your home feels meaningful, as does the world around you.  Just when you think you have seen everything the game has to offer, you see more--and not just new items with better stats.  The lore, awkward as it can be, does inspire genuine curiosity, and when I head off to explore, I never really know what I am going to find or where it will be found.  The monsters are more than just red-hot floating blobs of damage with slight variations on the same AI, and so different approaches to different enemies really does pay off so long as you are not over leveled.  I have 38 hours in this game because it is a very good game with a lot of potential, and it can only get better from here.  The developer's unique process, while unconventional, has created something I have thoroughly enjoyed.For what they are asking, this is game is a steal, and if you at all enjoyed Terraria, you should buy Crea.  It is not quite on par, but it is the closest to Terraria's heart and soul that any game has come in the years since.  Beyond the clear value to you as a consumer, these dedicated developers--so thoroughly involved with their community--genuinely deserve your money for what they have accomplished.  I want to see more heart in games, so I reward it when I see it.  I see it here.

Review Written on Wednesday, June 15th, 2016ReviewSo, this game just came out of Early Access a few days ago, and it deserved to, because the game looks good enough to be out already.If you never played Terraria or Starbound, to which this game is most similar to, you have for sure played, or heard about Minecraft, and this game is like Minecraft in 2D, but with way more content.You may think of it like a copy of Terraria/Starbound, but no, it has many gameplay differences, those that make the game unique in its own way.Rating:8.8/10Pros:Having two specials separate tabs, where there are 2 for fighting and one for building, for me was the most unique thing in the game, making it easier to split your fighting from your building.The Research Table was also something really new to me, where you have a piece of furniture where you learn to craft everything possible to, and where all your recipies are safe and sound.The Art and Music are pretty heartwarming and really good for a game design by such a small Developer.The skill tree is something that the game incorporated to define it from the other similar ones, where Terraria, for example, has multiple weapon types, this one has several skill points, making possible to have several buffs at the same time.The game is being constantly updated, with a team of Developers that, even though they are only two, if im not mistaken, they care a lot about their game, and take a lot in care what the community tells them.Cons:The game is not very Early Game friendly, too strong enemies with skills that you cannot fight against without proper equipment.The game lacks a proper tutorial, it does have some tips in early game, but it doesnt prepare you enough for what you will face.Before you have any skill points its pretty hard to do anything underground, unless you have enough dirt, for example, to build your way up again.Hardware InformationHardwareTypeMonitor1366x768HeadphonesOzone Rage STMouseE-Blue content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
Terr? Star? Crea! About the gameCrea is a 2D sandbox/crafting game with RPG typical RPG elements. It has a lot of similarities with the games of the same Genre like Terraria or Starbound: The world is randomly generated, you can gather almost anything you see, you can craft hundreads of things, battle monsters, etc. Yet it feels like a game of it's own. The cute art style, the talent trees and the diversity of the world make it stand out.A great feature in this game is the waypoint system, as you find crystals around the world, you can teleport between them and reach places you have already visited without having to walk all the way back or remember where it was.The RPG talent tree is really well done, whenever you perform actions in a certain category (Fighting, Exploration, Crafting, etc.) you gain points to spend in that category to improve it's efficiency.Overall it's a really great experience, wheter you like to explore, craft your own world or simply level up your character, you will have fun playing this game at least for a while.Also, If you enjoyed Terraria or Starbound, you should definately give this game a try!Pros:   Waypoint system RPG talent tree Crafting Exploration Variety of monsters Cons:   Networking / Lag Slow start / Enemies are much stronger than you would expect Sometimes unintuitive and lack of tutorial UI feels like it could get a massive rework Spells seems really bad/too slow for combat Rating: 9 out of 10 Disclaimer: Source of consideration: SiegeGames

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
If you like RPG and Sandbox, and have played things like Minecraft or Terraria, you'll love this.GAMEPLAY: Customisation is so much better compared to other games of this style. Crea is really based on building your own player in an RPG-type fashion, leveling up skills, y'know. Sandbox-wise, on the other hand, isn't as diverse as such.AUDIO: Soundtrack is a bit weird, not really my style. It's got that trance-y feel, but there's always the sound options.MULTIPLAYER: Not that great. Still has a IP, port, password-type interface. Kinda like the Blockheads if you've ever played that.WORLD DESIGN: Average. Not great, not bad. Expect something like the early release of Minecraft.BUGS: Yeah, early access. You know what that means; if you buy this, you'll get them. And it does come with this game; there are instances in which cursors will suddenly freeze, graphics will glitch, interactions are somewhat impossible, but just wait a while and it'll be fixed. Hopefully.OVERALL: A great game in the making, which will, hopefully, stray away from the likes of Starbound, Minecraft, Terraria etc. and become it's own type of sandbox-rpg. Highly recommended for those who like messing around with bits and pieces to make more bits and pieces, and also RPG lovers.3.8/5.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												This game is very clearly heavily influenced by Terraria, but it takes that influence and runs with it in its own direction.As someone who has dumped quite a lot of time into the sandbox craft/fight/dig games (mostly Minecraft, but also a bit of Terraria), the addition of a skill system in this game is a very welcome improvement. There's an actual sense of progression rather than just weakly gated tiers of items that you can rush through. Of course, there are item tiers as well, but at least at the early levels the skill progression seems to have just as much if not more impact.Coming from Terraria, the control scheme threw me off for a bit, as there are a total of four (4) hotbars, split between two modes (combat and exploration) and two tab groups each. After I got used to it, I came to appreciate the ergonomics, but there was a bit of a learning curve.Overall, quite impressed with this game thus far, but there are competing games at a lower price point that are probably better entry points into the genre.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
ReviewThis is a pleasantly relaxing sandbox game, with a mix of exploration, combat, crafting and building. I like how I'm not bound to any specific roll (mage, archer, swordsman, ect), and can technically switch rolls and playstyle throughout the game. But  my only gripe with the current leveling system is that you can't re-spec your points, because it feels like it should be a feature. One small different detail I really liked, was that putting points into Agility increases your range. Almost everything give points towards the different talents you can choice from. The researching system is one of my favorite parts of the game. Finding items reveals parts of recipes, so discovering and collecting felt more rewarding than usual. One optional part of the crafting was at first slightly confusing , is crafting with Chaos, as the tutorial is simplistic but not so detailed. It took a while to get used to switching between Crafting and Aggro Mode, but I'm glad that this feature was put in place. Because then you don't accidently attack animals passing by, but also it takes up less screen space than if there were two skill bars. When building, I like that I could place objects wherever I wanted on the ground, so nothing is locked to specific tile blocks on the ground. Someone recommended that I zoom the camera closer to the character, and I have to say, that being able to change the zoom around constantly made it a lot more enjoyable. Sometimes there is a split moment lag. During combat or It is understandable that there is a split moment of lag when discovering new terrain, but sometimes it'll happen during combat.  I've seen in the discussions that there are often bugs, even though it's out of early access, but luckily there are constant updates being added into the game. Pros: Enjoyable  RPG elements , such as an experience system with talents/skills. The researching and crafting system. A lot of decent content: monsters, weapons, quick-travel, ect. Excellent arrange of settings (such as zooming in/out). Regularly updated for bugs. Mixed:Takes some time to learn essential talents , such as wall-grabbing and double-jumping. Cons:Currently can't respec  your skill points. Sometimes there is a split moment lag. Final Comment and Rating:It has most of the same mechanics that you'd expect from somewhat similar 2D crafting sandbox games, and on top of that, has RPG elements. There are plenty of items, beautiful art style, plenty of items and monsters. Overall a great CREAtive world.  8 / 10Disclaimer: Played with a review copy. 
Source of consideration: Siege Games

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												"Now this game will get good!"This game is basically Terraria with a more complex crafting system.  What's not to love?Unfortunately, the crafting system is poorly thought out and implemented.  Sure I "could" create lots of cool armor, walking up the stats tree, but unfortunately that game doesn't really seem to work that way.  I know tons of recipes, have loads of components, but for some reason the components are grayed out.  Need a studded vest to make the improved vest?  You have 2?  No matter, it's still greyed out.  No tool tip explaining why, just it is.You are constantly hitting your head in research, as your crafting level isn't high enough to research new items.  Fine, but your crafting skill improves by researching new items, so you are basically screwed, except by getting recipes from scraps.  These can be very hard to come by early, having to find them in chests and pots, but after a bit, hey you can now get these scraps occasionally by mining ore.  Great!  Except the trickle is so small it doesn't really help that much.So later, you get a Scrapper, which can change junk you have collected and convert them into scraps.   Great, except the exchange rates seem all over the place.  Very generous for some components, such as vines, but stingy as hell for true items, such as bows.  By the way, why can't I scrap certain items?   No clue, you just can't.No worries anyhow, as even though research via scraps gets easier, you can't make most of the recipes you have anyway,  Some compoents are too rare to get.  For example, it seems many many items are gated by the need for Lonis seeds.  They are needed to make entry level items, which are needed to make the next level etc. etc. etc.  But I never did find a single seed in the wild.  Finally after getting creating an NPC which sells items, I was able to buy a few and cultivate my own, though that only led me to more greyed out components.  Again, no clue why they are greyed out.I could go on and on, but hopefully you get my drift.  Poor documentation, and very little in-game information finally got me to delete the game from my computer.  Every time I thought I had jumped through the last hoop, so that the game was about to get good, nope, just more B.S.Other flaws?  Poorly designed hot keys and tool bars really stand out.  Sure, you could get lots of cool spells, but then again, you only get access to five at a time, each with cooldowns.  If you use up two slots with healing spells, what's the point of knowing 10 other spells?The inventory system has little to help you organize you pack.It's overly difficult to compare item's you find or are considering crafting to what you have currently equiped.  It sure would have been nice to show the specs of what is currently equiped in the details popup on the item you are looking at.And let no talk too much about the map!  Not a mini map, but a full map.  No true mini map is available, though the map does have a useless mode, what it is drawn on the screen at the same time your landscape is drawn.  This map is the ugliest P.O,S, map I have ever seen,  Not to say there aren't positive aspects to the game.  I thought the creating your own NPCs by dressing up mannequins was a clever idea, though most of these NPCs are worthless after a couple of quick interactions.The game generally looks nice, though most just a clone of Terraria.Perhaps one day enough polish will be added to make the game enjoyable, but boy, it's just not there yet.

number of helpful: 14 of 27 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crea is another one of those Terraria-like games that sucks your time in like nobody's business. Though, Crea differentiates itself from the usual 2D voxel games with its rewarding talents system. Yes, you've got the usual mine-craft-fight mechanic, but now you've also got skills to manage that improves your game. It's a bit like Skyrim's where you accumulate points (TP) in certain talent areas based on what you do, then spend those points on perks. It's interesting and rewarding since certain perks actually change up the gameplay a bit (like being able to ledge grab, or being able to mine more than one block).The combat is actually fun, with dodge rolls, combos, and blocking mechanics. What's also interesting is the "Style" system, which is essentially Crea's magic-based combat. It's a bit finicky since most enemies move so fast (while you have a casting time), but fun when you get it right. The Style system plays differently in that you need to accumulate a number of charges by casting its base form (heal self, throw fireball, etc). Once you've got enough, then you can cast upgraded forms like fire pillars or ice beams or whatever. Definitely interesting, but gimped since melee is still better.For mining, I like that you only need one tool to break the world (well, two: one for breaking stuff, and your hands for picking up stuff in place like furnaces and anvils). It's slow at first, but it's mitigated by the Talent system's upgrades.Crafting is one of the gripes I have. It's the typical have-these-to-make-that, or have-these-and-be-near-this-to-make that, but the crafting menu seriously needs an overhaul. There's a filter, sure, but it's not very intuitive. I prefer the usual categorization of crafting items rather than having it all out.Graphics are pretty decent as well. It's like Terraria in terms of tone, but with a much more polished look. My other gripe is the lack of purpose. That's true for most voxel games, though, and Crea is no different. "Here's the world, and here's a pickaxe. Bye!" I think it would really improve the experience if the game had towns or NPCs to interact with (talk, fight, barter, whatever). I think the only voxel game that nailed this artificial community aspect was WindForge. Overall, Crea is a lot of fun. It's deeper than other Terraria clones thanks to its skill system, and the graphics are fun. I'd have been all over this game if it weren't for the general lack of purpose.

								Crea, a sandbox game that I supported via Kickstarter, is now available via the Steam early access program. It's continuing to change and the developers appear to be committed to moving the title forward.  The developers also interact with users, via the forums here, on their website and Twitch.  Even in it's current state, I find this title to be engaging and it's easy to get lost in the game while exploring it's procedurally generated worlds (and worlds within worlds).

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Sunday, June 12th, 2016 Review This game is an awesome and is addictive with Starbound and Terraria elements to it, but with its own type of flavor. The game is early access has occasional hiccups, but can be easily fixed with an update or two. It’s a refreshing take on 2D sandbox/rpg type of games which is a good commodity. Let’s start with the gameplay. It starts out rather easy as you can get a short tutorial on what to do. You can easily manage controls on an Xbox controller or PlayStation controller which can be helpful. The graphics are pixelated like any other retro game. I’m a fan of these retro games as I grew up in the 80's and 90's playing those console games in their prime. The skilling up/leveling up system is very unique and different from Starbound and Terraria which makes this game stand on its own. I enjoyed exploring and creating my homes, teleport points, forges, and loved the crafting aspect inside of it. This game is very time consuming and can be very addictive at the same time. The game isn’t perfect and still is an early access game which comes with its bugs and glitches. The game has unusually long load times when you first start out which I found awkward knowing this is a pixel 2d sandbox game and isn’t a really big game that should be doing so. I found that it did take much more memory than expected as well which I heard the developer is seeking to fix. In terms of the multiplayer aspect, there should be some dedicated servers steam side to help everyone connect with each other to make this game even more fun. I hope that this is also fixed and implemented in the finalized version so I can even give this a higher grade on my review. Anyways I found this game to be quite fun, addictive, time consuming, and refreshingly new. I hope this game can fix these glitches and whatnot to make this an even better game.Rating: 7.5/10 Pros:  Refreshingly new take on skilling/leveling up system Smooth/solid gameplay with either controller or keyboard Music is mesmerizing and soothing to keep the gameplay running smoothly as well Fun Crafting and exploring Mods can be implemented in the game  Cons:  Occasional hiccups that may cause sluggish gameplay momentarily Sometimes glitchy scenery/enemies Unusually long load times at certain points of the game No dedicated servers otherwise I can give this higher rating There are often multiplayer connection timeouts  Hardware Information   Hardware Type   Monitor Samsung Series 9 S27B970D Display Port 2560x1440   Headphones Astro A40 Headset   Keyboard CMStorm KB   Controller Xbox 360 Wired Controller   Mouse Logitech - G900 Chaos Spectrum   Microphone Astro A40 Mic   Motherboard ASRock X79 Professional   CPU Intel i7-4930K 340GHz   GPU Nvidia GeForce GTX 760 X 2   RAM 16 GB Ram   OS Windows 7 Pro   HDD WD 2TB Hdd  Disclaimer: Source of consideration: Siege Games

Review Written on Monday, June 14th, 2016ReviewUpon first glance of Crea you might get the vibes which says, this game looks just like Terraria but less 16-bit pixel graphic. Well part of it is same, the genre and style is similar to Terraria actually. But! in Crea you have a leveling system, a research system, and the crafting system well placed and easy to use and understand even without the need of tutorial. Something I would like however is a larger inventory capacity.I haven't played the largest map yet, the tryout I had was on the smallest map. Even on a small map you can expect lots of play hour. Since on your first go with a new character you want to build my leveling up so you can hit harder and collect materials faster. So if you like sandbox games but you think 3d sandbox like Minecraft is too big, and you don't feel Terraria is pretty, then I think you should give Crea a try. So far I have enjoyed the hours I spent on it. Here's a list of improvement I think Crea has over Terraria:Crisp graphicLevel up systemEasy craftingSome users has complained about bugs, from my experience I only had one occassion in which I had to restart the game, because my controller stopped to work for some reason. Except for that I haven't experience any problem with the game. Moreover the developer is very active and I believe the reported bugs are quickly fixed. So you don't need to worry about you bought a broken game ;)Rating:8.5/10Pros:Crisp graphic, if you prefer less pixelLevel up systemEasy to understand crafting systemResearch instead of recipesCons:If you careless go inside a cave and falls down in a hole you be stuck there forever.Too few customization option when creating your characterToo small graphic, but I guess if you zoom it in it would look too much like Terraria maybe?Hardware InformationHardwareTypeMonitor24HeadphonesHeadphonesKeyboardRazor black widowControllerxbox360 gamepadMouselogitech g602MicrophoneMicrophoneMotherboardasrock xtreme3CPUi5GPU660tiRAM24gb dd3OSwin10HDDHDDDisclaimer:Source of consideration: Siege Games

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												I want to preface this by stating that I got a copy for both my friend and i, and got 4 other people to get copies. That's how much i like this game.Okay now into the detailed part of my assessment.There are some things you should know about this game:The game is not finished. There is still a lot more to be done, bugs to be fixed, features planned, and so on.There is A LOT of content in it currently. I am this far into the game and still discovering new things.The customization with different armours and weapons and accessories is CRAZY OVERWHELMING (in a good way)It shares many similarities to that of Starbound and Terraria, with a complex leveling and skill system, along with a researching system in which you use items to learn their uses, which i believe makes perfect sense.The bosses (may change in the future) are incredibly beautiful. I love their art, he really did a great job on them. There's only 4 in game at the moment, with more to be plannedYes there are bugs.There are some pretty gamebreaking bugs that will either ruin the game for you, or for your friends playing with you.He is CONSTANTLY working on them at https://www.twitch.tv/siegegames for all of you to say, talking to the fans, seeing what they want, and what needs fixed. I have seen him resolve issues he had no idea how to fix, simply with help from fans, and the information they provided live on stream.TLDR: This is an amazing game. It has bugs. It's not completely finished. but this shows SO MUCH PROMISE.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Alrighty. I don't see how I can run Arma 3 at 120+ frames. But on this, I get 30 tops... Optimize.Other than that, the concept it cool I guess. Pretty much the same thing as Terraria, but with a twist. Terraria is obviously better than this game, but Crea is, different enough I suppose, to be considered a different game... Maybe not. Hostile slimes when you spawn? I, I dont know. I couldn't get that far in the game considering I was stuttering like Eric Maye. Look up Eric Maye. Thats pretty much this games performance in a nutshell... I don't want it to sound like Im dogging on this game, because if that is indeed is what im doing, I also want to point out that this game does have potential. All this game needs is an optimization update. Then I'll be all over this, but till then. I'm putting this guy up on the shelf.*EDIT* I don't know what you did my man, but the game no longer lags. Thank you for keeping to your word, I respect 'dat. Now, as for the Crea, Now that I've had time to sit down and play. It, is really cool xD So many monsters on the surface? Er ma gerd! Different attacks too! I was running away from one dude, and the guy pulled up an ice wall in front of me, I mean wow. Very cool indeed. Im eager to see what some next in this.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Let's make this abundantly clear. This game does have it's bugs, and there's a number of them; but that shouldn't be the absolute decided factor between picking up this game in my opinion. Jasson (Siege Games main developer) does a weekly live stream where he let's players chat and discuss various issues with the game. He is, without a doubt, 100% on top of all issues that are being addressed.Now, in my experience thus far, I actually haven't came across a single bug that's been mentioned by other players. More specifically, Audio/Graphic issues. I have 14.4 hours (as of this review) and I've yet to experience one hiccup. The game itself has enough content for a CASUAL gamer. You have boss fights, you have character progression, you have researching/crafting. There's plenty of pros to this game in it's current state, and that will only continue to grow.One thing I see that's mentioned quite a bit is the learning curve. Here's what you need to understand. The game is new, and the fanbase is relatively small currently (Approx. ~1000 players). The Wiki doesn't have much information, so you're really reliant on exploring the game yourself and actually taking the time to LEARN it. If that's something you don't want to do, and you just want a mindless tutorial you're going to skip over anyways, then this isn't the game for you. The best way to learn the game currently IS TO PLAY IT.At first, I was extremely intimidated by the game. I spawned next to a crystal with what seemed to be a teleporting option; I quickly ignored it and moved on. A few hours in I really started to understand it's purpose. For nearly 10 hours of gameplay, I had NO idea you could use spells such as proficiencies, in passive mode. I kept switching to attack mode to cast my spells. Again, I figured this out because I PLAYED the game.TL;DR:The game isn't in bad shape at all. There's major and minor bugs, but every game will have those. Stick with the developer, report the bugs, and I PROMISE this will make Terraria seem like a childs game. Also, on a side note. Jasson is the only developer, and on his stream June 13th, he mentioned wanting to hire a C++ coder to help fix bugs and improve content. One thing I truly admired about him was his excitement seeing people on Twitch playing his game. He's clearly working his very hardest to listen to players and fix big issues. He took questions/issues DIRECTLY from viewers on Twitch and fixed them right in front of your eyes. The guy shows a lot of promise, and so does this game. I highly recommend picking it up while it's $15. One thing I do recommend (this is for Siege Games), ask some big players of your game to help expand the content of your Wiki. Provide starter guides, more explanations, and clarifications on items/crafting/chaos. Let your players help other players.

												This game gets a bad rep from all of the people expecting it to be just as huge as Terraria is. Yes, it's in the same genre of game with a similar style and feel, but that doesn't mean it has to be the same game re-skinned. The crafting may be simpler, but I honestly prefer it. It feels a lot less confusing than Terraria is, with a much smaller learning curve. The art is A+, and the music is great. And my good sweet lordy, the leveling system just gives you something that Terraria and other sandbox games were missing! This game is fun and engaging, and I would recommend you wait till it's on sale and then try it out.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This is one of my favorite games on steam, even though I have not played very much. It is like a combination of Starbound and Terraria, and has many other things as well. The research system makes things a bit more difficult and helps to balance out the loot you often get when you go into dungeons or high level areas. The idea of things getting harder as you go out into the world is one of my favorite features and really helps to make the game interesting. You have to take risks and go out farther to find rare materials as well as to level up faster when facing tougher enemies. I also really enjoy the chaos crafting mini game (even though I am terrible at it) because the increased chances of modifiers and quality can make a very powerful weapon or tool. The talent leveling system is also pretty good, you have to use the talent a good bit to improve upon your skill in it. There is also a character leveling system which gives stat points as well as improving all stats. The bosses seem to level up as you defeat them over and over, so that is nice, is keeps the game interesting. Well, one boss is always the same level as the player which means that boss fight is pretty even unless the player improves their combat talents. Again, this is one of my favorite games and I can't wait to see what's in store for it.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Product received for free
 Crea: An interesting 2D sandbox with a focus on RPG elements  Crea is a very fun addictive 2D sandbox game. Although it may at first glance seem similar to other competitors such as Terraria, the game strives to provide a unique experience through its unique talent and research systems.  Pros: + Great Art Style and overall feel. + The research system is really cool. It works by consuming items in your inventory that are in a specific recipe to in turn unlock partial knowledge of that recipe as a whole. I was truly surprised as to how well this system fits into a game like this, not to mention how well the crafting system works alongside this.+ The talent system works great and feels well implemented into a game of this nature. It is extremely fun both level up and improving your player's stats, as well as improving various perks in different skills that all rank up independently from each other.+Great amount of exploration and lots to do.+Trading Cards, Achievements, Workshop Support, etc.+ Mac and Linux Ports much appreciated. It only took Terraria like 2 years and millions of sales to make some of those. Cons: - REALLY BAD STUTTERING ISSUES. Although my frames per second was generally good (30-40 fps) considering my lower end hardware, the game would often freeze for multiple seconds at a time. This was mostly apparent during combat and crafting and was also reported by other users.- Decent amount of bugs (Although the game did just release from early access)-No Dedicated Servers- LACK OF EXPLANATION: While there is some tutorial, the game could do alot better at explaining some of these elements.  It almost seems as though the developer assumed everyone playing also owned similar games such as Terraria or Starbound, and the game as a result is very unfriendly to beginners. There are various community guides to help supplement this thankfully, and although the game may be hard for some to initially get through with enough time this can be overcome.  Overall Assessment Crea is certainly an extremely well thought out and well made game, and its unique research and talent systems alone make it worth buying.  Although, if you haven't played other similar games such as Terraria and Starbound, you may want to take a look at them first to get a grasp of the genre and how to play these kinds of games. However, if you've already played Terarria, enjoy RPG elements, and don't care about dedicated servers, Crea is definitely worth a purchase.  Just beware of some stuttering issues if your computer is lower end.VisGaming Score: 7.5/10 I received this product for reviewing purposes from Siege Games. 
This did not effect my review or rating in any way.

								I was having a great time, spent most of the day on this levelling up, building stuff - great and splendid time.Then a sudden crash and blue screen.  Ok, no problem. My actual world and 'stuff' was intact, but really don't fancy another 6 hours of grinding to get back to where I was skillwise, so I'll not be playing this anymore until the data can be sorted out.  Otherwise a great game with lots of promise - would have just liked a warning about 'your character will randomly disappear or get rolled back' - whilst I understand its early access and this may eventually happen, having it happen mid-play-session is a non-starter.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Sunday, June 12th, 2016 Review Crea is a 2D sandbox RPG, with pixel-art graphics. It instantly reminds of Terraria, and for good reason of course. It is obvious where the devs took their inspiration from. This is not to say that this is a negative thing. Not at all, as they have done a great job with this game offering hours of gameplay with variety. You start out with basic tools such as a club and chopping/digging tool. As you progress through the game by gaining experience you are able to get talent points, which can be used to increase your combat skills or to improve your gathering productivity. When leveling up you are also able to distribute points across different character stats, such as health, stamina, attack, defense, agility etc. An important factor of this game of course, is its crafting ability. You use resources which you can gather throughout the games world, things like flora and minerals. You can craft a wide range of items, whether this be gear, housing or improved tools. It took a while for me to get used to the crafting, but after the initial confusion it becomes self-explanatory. Rating: 7.5/10 Pros:  Great UI. Everything is done very intuitively, whether this involves the settings of the game, the various hotkeys or simply the placing of UI elements. It is obvious that the dev put a lot of effort into this. The game contains a wide range of controls, which are fully rebindable. Big plus from me. Pixel-art, you either love it or hate it. I definitely love it, and it fits the game well. The game contains both single-player and multiplayer. Supports mods, so I hope this will keep the game going with new and refreshing content.  Cons:  Please improve the tutorials. While I do appreciate the game having them, it could - and should - be done better. Personal preference of course, but I thought the sound effects were rather annoying and the music spread out scarcely. The loading times take way too long on my high-end system, which I find odd. Might be nice to have a wiki containing craft-abilities and more information on how to play the game. content:
Posted: April 24
												It's really hard to explain just how bad this game is. My issue was that despite my early misgivings, I kept thinking the game would 'open up' after the 4 hours mark, and so I kept playing. Once I reached the first boss, that was when I knew...This game suffers from No Man's Sky syndrome."What is NMS Syndrome?", you may ask. Great question! It's a special sort of suffering that comes about when a game has just enough intrigue and promise to make you play past Steam's refund period, and then instantly drops off afterwards.The problems with this game are not going to be fixed without a total rework and transformation into a totally different game, but let me go ahead and waste my time explaining to you just how extensive they are.Music:This might seem to be a silly thing to start with, but my god the music in this game is the blandest most boring OST I have ever heard. It's tough to even call it music, honestly. This was always my biggest problem with it. Once you realize there is no 'action' in the game and it's truly a slow, plodding, boring experience, the music begins to make sense, but by then you've already lost all hope.If anything could start to make a dent in the playability of this game, making the music more interesting would be a big first step. Compare this to Terraria, which I consider the gold standard for indie game music. The music changes based on where you are in a planet, and it not only fits the general mood of an area, it also can help set the mood, like when you enter the Dungeon for the first time.Crea? The bosses don't even have different music. It's the same bland overworld track you've been listening to for 3 hours straight!Night-time/Day-time? Same music!Underground? Hey, the music changes a little bit! Too bad it's still boring.TL:DR, the music in this game is below sub-par, it might as well not even be there.User Interaction:One of the reasons I bought this game was because of the big lauded User Interface upgrade that I saw so much about and how excited people were for it. Guess what?...it's good. Like, the UI isn't bad at all.But the control scheme for this game is the worst thing I have experienced barring $0.99 games being resold from 1995 on Steam. I don't even know how to explain this, but here goes.1. You have two main 'control schemes' you must use. One is for exploration, the other is for combat.2. Each control scheme has a sort of alternate scheme you can switch from. As an example, you can have a melee/ranged and a magic loudout for your character, then your other scheme will be for exploration with magic spells to detect ore and such.3. So let's say you're playing with your sword and bow scheme. LMB will likely attack with the sword, and RMB will charge up and shoot your arrow. Want to switch to magic? Maybe you, like me, binded it to scroll-wheel-down. But if you want to switch to exploration mode, with your pickaxe and torches and stuff? That's a totally different button.4a. It gets better. The buttons you need to press change depending on what mode you're in. For example, in exploration mode, if you have a spell like the 'locate ore' spell on your hotbar in the '4' position, pressing 4 does not activate the spell. Instead, after pressing 4, you have to press RMB to activate it!4b. But let's say you're in combat mode, with your wands in hand and spells at the ready with Fireball tagged to the 4 slot. Pressing '4' DOES cast the spell! WHAT?!5a. Your actions against the lower hotbars also change depending on what menu you are viewing. For example, let's say you're in combat mode and there's an enemy coming. You don't have any of your inventory/character/talent windows or etc open, so if you right-click on fireball on your quick menu, it will cast Fireball.5b. But then let's say that you DO have an inventory or talent menu open... if you don't realize this and right-click on Fireball... it will delete the god-damn spell from your hotbar! The enymy was already close by, now you have to frantically open up your talent menu, scroll to the fireball spell, drag it to your hotbar, close the menu, then right-click it again to cast it! Oops, you died!6. This one is more agregious, because of how asinine it is. In Exploration Mode, left clicking removes an object or mines a tile... and right click places one. Further, when you pluck comething out of your inventory, like a crafting table, and you then right click to place it... it doesn't place it! You often have to right-click twice! God forbid you left-click instead, you'll be baffled as to why you can't place this item down.Oh no! An enemy is attacking! You're in exploration mode underground, and you need to switch to your weapons in a hurry! What do you do? In your panic, you hit scroll-wheel-down, but alas... that switches to your alternate exploration loadout. So you hit your other button and now you're in magic mode... but oops! You forgot to place a torch somewhere so now you're in total darkness! (Unlike in Terraria, you can't hold shift for a split second to illuminate your surroundings with a torch in your inventory)You quicklly press the other button and swap your loadout to melee since this is CQC, but you're still totally blind. Swinging wildly, you quickly die. Or you try to run blindly, fall off a ledge, and take a ridiculous amount of fall damage.All I'm saying is that the control scheme in this game is abominable. But even all of what I've said pales in comparison to the next point..."""Sandbox""" Progression:You know what I think makes Terraria great? You can be as good as you want at the game and it's all skill based. Sure, you might only be doing one-damage to the boss with each arrow you fire, but you're still actually damaging him. In Crea, you will often be fighting enemies at a much higher level than you and not be damaging them at all. Let's dive into core gameplay.Leveling Up:In Crea, as you perform an activity, you gain EXP for that thing. You have Arms, magic, exploration, crafting, and gathering.Arms is your physical attacks and such. This includes melee and ranged weapons like bows. (All right, just bows. No guns or anything cool.)Magic is obviously stuff related to magic, mostly meaning spells.Exploration is gained literally by walking around, and boosted by walking in areas you haven't been before, moreso in high level areas. This category also includes mobility upgrades like a double jump and sprinting.Crafting is leveled by crafting items, researching, etc. It not only allows you to refine items better, but get better sell prices and such.Gather is gained when you pick up items, dig in the ground, etc. It includes a few 'spells' that allow you to see ore and treasure chests and stuff, plus lots of upgrades for mining speed and etc.So the fundamental issue with leveling, especially in Crea, is that it just flatly locks you out of everything. In Terraria, double jumps can be obtained by finding a cloud in a bottle, and you might literally luck out and find those in a surface level chest five minutes into the game. In Crea, you're guaranteed 5 hours of grinding before you gain such a simple thing.But the real issue is what leveling and stats do to the gameplay experience. Crea has leveled zones, meaning the further you are from spawn, the stronger the enemies are, to the point of just one-shotting you. Three of your leveling traits gain you zero combat survivability. The only way to increase your actual player level is to grind in combat by attacking every single enemy you see, and it takes a LONG time........I hit the character limit for steam reviews. I really wanted to continue ripping this game to shreds but now I'm bored. Fantastic, that was effort wasted. Didn't know the limit existed.

												I like this genre and have played many hours of Terraria and Starbound. I picked up Crea to give it a try and have enjoyed the gameplay, so far. The graphics aren't bad and there is controller support, unlike the previously mentioned games. I like the crafting system and how there are various levels to it. It gives me something to look forward to when exploring and leveling up my character. In any case, I would give this game a try if you like exploration and crafting games.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												Terraria with rpg elements. Better than starbound.DISCLAIMER: In order to smelt ores and craft items efficiently in this game you must endure one of the least entertaining mini games ever concieved. You click on a number of abilities to max out the items quality before its chaos rating fills up. However, each of your abilities used to craft is simply a dice roll. The variation on the rolls is very large. Large to the point of it feeling completely pointless each time you use an ability as it is possilbe to completely fill out your chaos on an ability that is necessary to use in a single click. Pretty much everytime you click something you run the risk of trashing the item and wasting all the resources. This same process is used to smelt ores. Instead of just smelting all the ores you bring back you have to do this frustrating minigame for EVERY SINGLE BAR YOU SMELT. Sure you could just smelt it normally, but you will recieve 1/2 - 1/3 as much ore as you would by torturing yourself with the chaos crafting system. You will be motivated to go through this because you need as much smelted as possible to try the "minigame" (random dice roll) when crafting the actual items as many times as possible in hopes of getting an item with something besides pickup distance. It is hard to really determine how much fun the rest of the game is because in comparison to the crafting system everything is amazing.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												I think this is the first review I have written for a computer game.  The reason I am taking the time to write this review is because I want the reader to know that the developer, Jasson, is very competent and very available and responsive.  The game is fun and playable and being constantly updated, with new content planned.  Whenever an update breaks something, Jason is on it and fixes the problem.  For example, version 1.0.10 was an unstable opt-in beta attempt to fix some multiplayer issues.  It did fix some of the issues but created others.  We just clicked on the live stream button in the game which took us right to Jasson live, then he reproduced the problem, tracked down three issues and fixed them, and had a new version 1.0,12 out the same day.  Now we are up and playing again,  The problems that are left are minor annoyances which Jason is aware of and is working daily to fix, and will have fixed them all soon.  This game is worth the money, and the developers back their product and give the highest level of service and help imaginable, in my humble opinion.  I am totally happy with the game and with my experience with the developer.  My wife and I have played over 150 hours and are looking forward to new content and further developemet of this game and concept.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												I bought this game exactly to get away from Terraria.. Whatever new thing is added there It's going straight for the end game. While this here is something new and people make the same Minecraft mistake as always - comparing one game to another which is considered superior.. But I wouldn't call it that way because this game has some things that Terraria doesn't have. CONS:- You can move the inventory menus.- The Gathering / Combat switch is great - we all expirienced the pick to be at button 6 while the sword is on 1...- The research system is something new, many people may complain about it, but every game has its element, which's sole purpose is to "waste" your time in a good way - head in the game.- Huge talent system.- Classic RPG elements.Of course, every game has it's own..CONS:- Lag spikes/ Frame Rate drop - nothing is more capable than this to ruin your game and sadly this game has this problem.- Not so much content when talking about Mobs.- Multiplayer is somehow left.. unfinished.. while you can play with your friends, it's just not supported on steam, and that makes things a little bit uncomfortable.- In the settings there arent many graphic options. Only in-game, and still the only two which will help you reduce the lag spikes are V-sync disable and Lightning.- Beginner Unfriendly.Overall :While this is everything I had to say until this moment about pros and cons, I don't thing there is any need this game to be rated.. not in this early stage. It has great potential, just a little bit witch the wrench here and there. I do not regret buying the game simply because I'm sure that in 4-5 months this game will have at least 200 downloads a day.7.8 / 10

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												Dou you like Terraria, Starbound, Minecraft? Then don't play this game. It's way way worse than any of those.The game can be described in these 4 words: unintuitive, messy, underdeveloped and monotonous.1. The tutorial is pretty poor/incomplete. Same for game's wiki. You will have to google pretty often for core game mechanics, item recipies etc. 2. UI is as bad as it can be. It's unintuitive, overcomplicated, unfriendly, poorly documented and inconsistent. It's a constant pain and struggle.3. Forget diversity. The game is pretty monotonous. Even soundtrack only has a single main theme. There is nothing like Terraria events or Starbound quests,4. The skills system that is advertised as an advantage over Terraria/Starbound/Minecraft is in fact not sweet at all. Many skills are useles: some of them will be irrelevant for you because you follow one specific skill build (e.g. warrior, not mage). Another reason why having many skills is not cool is UI: there is almost no way one will use more than 3-5 active skills. And there is casting delay. And there is stamina cost. Bottom line is that skills system is not fun at all.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												As much as a good game this is I can far from recommend it.8 hours play time and can still not make stairs or ladders and have yet to see a single NPC.The entire crafting system builds on a weird mechanic of researching. Everything seems to be random and like I said, I can after 8 hours craft various beds, chairs, chrystal stuff but no ladder och stairs!There are a lot of bugs still and I know the dev is working hard.Enemies have a weird scale as well, you can attack a lvl 1 monster and get a portal to a realm where the monster are higher lvl than you, and then you die if your not really careful. So a lvl 1 monster and you thinking "oh nice, some easy loot in this realm" can turn in to a 20 min attack and run fest.The crafting system I like very much, but there are some weird combinations that make no sense.The combat system is probably the most well thought in this game. Good variety of combos, spells and attacks. And depending on what you do (swords or magic) you gain levels in that specific category.It sadens me to say that I'd much rather keep playing Terraria (1000+ hours) and/or Starbound. This game feels more like a Early Access than anything else.

												Crea is a 2D sandbox type game that blends exploration, building, crafting and combat all into one universe. While it's easy to compare the game to others like Terraria and Starbound I would say that based on the systems present in the game, it tends to lean more on the RPG  side of things. Unfortunately the art style of Crea does not appeal to me but this in no way affects the gameplay. One of the main reasons I'll praise this game over similar titles is the full controller support. I absolutely despise playing this genre with a keyboard and mouse. It just personally feels clunky to me and while Crea may not be the best in its class, overall I would hope for continued updates and improvements over time.I received this game for free in exchange for my honest review.
