content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I don't think there's much I can add to the numerous reviews already here, but I'm going to go ahead and add my opinion anyhow.I've played the game some.  And then some.  I've never played Terraria (beyond the first few minutes of trying it), and never playing Starbound (though it's on my wishlist).  So playing this presented a new type of challenge for me.  I like platformers, I like building houses, I like exploring, I like crafting.  Perfect!  Backtracking a little, I like recipe based crafting.  I don't like Minecraft style crafting where you put certain things in certain places and hope for the best.  Wood + metal = Barrel!  I shouldn't have to worry about the design necessary to create it.  (Some people like to...  that's fine with me.  I don't.)Early game I found myself getting my butt kicked...  mercilessly.  Again, new style of game...  plus playing a platformer on a keyboard has never been particularly easy for me (I'll rock MegaMan on a controller all day long though).  As I learned the enemies, their attacks, and my own skills I became a much more profecient killer.  Now, at level 50 with 50 Arms level...  there isn't a damn thing that frightens me.  (Aside from the dark.  That's still scary.)There are beginners guides out there if you need them, or just want them.  I'll just give a little tip...  gather.  Stone, wood, and especially ore early game...  that's what it's all about.  Investing in good armor will save your♥♥♥♥♥too.  Also, when you find boxes and loot them, feel free to gather the box too.  Bows are tricky but allow you to stay mobile.  Also, pressing down while holding either direction will cause you to tumble.  You will avoid all damage while doing this...  including falling damage (there's an achievement associated with this).Learning new recipes can be challenging.  You learn stuff based on material drops you've gotten, or things you've crafted.  Keeping a researcher near your boxes keeps you from having to grab items from your boxes in order to see if you can learn something new.  Additionally, most materials have different rarity tiers.  (White, green, blue, purple, gold...  just like rarity for weapons and armor.)The developer is great, he's always working on the game and generally streams as he's doing it.  He's constantly reading the comments/questions on his channel and answering them while he works too.  So far he's the first (and only) Twitch subscription I have.  Updates are released frequently, which is great.Lastly, dungeons are instanced temporary maps that have different goals.  The end goal is always to make it to the crystal, but some times you have to avoid damaging monsters, sometimes you have to kill them all, sometimes you just have to flip switches.  There are also different affects applied to your character or the mobs making the instances constantly different (to an extent).The ultra rare stuff is hard to find.  I have yet to find some things and I have most all of the bosses on farm mode and have traveled to the four corners of the map.All in all, I recommend the game.  It isn't perfect but Jasson strives at getting it there, and then revamping what already exists.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Product received for free
Review Written on Sunday, June 26th, 2016ReviewThis game is an unmistakable descendant of Terraria, and it stays true to the look and feel of the original with many similar game play elements. However, there is enough innovation and variation here to make it well worth playing. It's a relaxed, explore-at-your-own-pace game -- ideal as an enjoyable, long-running endeavor to play whenever you have some free time. Drop in to explore, collect resources, expand your home base, kill some ugly creatures, and then call it a day. Your world is saved and will be waiting for you to explore and build when you return.If you need high-octane battles and constant action, youll not find a happy home here. On the other hand if you enjoy exploring and learning, there is more than enough depth to keep you entertained for many hours. Progression is limited by how much you have leveled up your talents and how much research you've managed to complete. Both of which gently guide you toward the next thing you need to learn in order to advance. The environment is forgiving, and the consequences of dying are almost none; you can feel free to give any idea a whirl.Having played 50+ hours so far, there have been many aha! moments, but there is still a lot to learn. Its quite addicting if youre prone to getting lost in the details with games like this. When you divide the price by the number of hours worth of quiet enjoyment you can get out of this, it looks like a real deal. Even better if you have friends who play and you can arrange some multiplayer fun along the way.Rating:9.0/10Pros:True to the original without being a cloneVery active developer, continuing to improve the gameRuns very well under Linux, even on a modest laptop.Completely playable and fun as single-user, but multiplayer is supported tooSome clever control features, which remove the tedium of moving around in worldCons:A few user-interface actions are not quite as obvious as they could beThe tutorial is very basic and youre on your own to discover how things workThe web site creawiki.net is full of spoilers :-)Over 50 hours of play, had a single game crashI should be doing my actual work instead of crafting and building.Hardware InformationHardwareTypeMonitorAcer AL2416WHeadphones-nope-KeyboardLogitechController-none-MouseLogitechMicrophone-none-MotherboardMSI Z77A-GD65CPUIntel i5-3570KGPURadeon R7 260XRAM8GOSFedora LinuxHDD250G SSDDisclaimer:Source of consideration: Siege Games provided a gratis review copy.

												The UI for this game is probably one of the clunkiest I've ever seen. Not only is it a hassle to just access items and actually build, but it is painfully slow when everything else in the game runs smoothly. For example, if I wanted to place down a torch while exploring, I would need to stop whatever I'm doing, open my inventory, grab the torches, place one down, and put them back in my inventory. In games like Terraria and Starbound, you could have items in a sort of hotbar where you easily access them while on the go, making exploring easier and faster. With Crea it just feels like a chore. Building is no better, with you having slowly place down each block one at a time. And as I mentioned before the UI is horribly slow. When I first entered the game the UI wasn't even there, it took almost a solid minute to appear. I couldn't build, couldn't research, I couldn't even see my inventory. Research is also kind of confusing. The game will tell me that I've unlocked an item, but when I actually try to craft it, its nowhere to be seen. I'm not sure if this is a bug, or maybe I'm just doing something wrong but I have no way of knowing. Besides the UI issues and bugs, the game is okay I guess. I mean I can tell that alot of effort went into making this but in the end it just ends up feeling like a second-rate terraria. It does have alot of original things going for it like the fighting and leveling system. The music and art style are nice too, but as for the game as a whole, I just can't reccomend it. Overall I'd give it maybe a 4-5/10. At least the developer is active and is currently addressing many of the bugs within the game, but in my opinion the game should have stayed in early access.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												Crea is a game that is similar to Terraria, but at the same time, quite different. Fans of the Minecraft modding scene may remember a mod called 'Thaumcraft 3', the one where you needed to get materials and research them to unlock more recipies. This game has that as a core element, and it's a feature I quite like. You have an RPG leveling system in here, where you can upgrade your basic stats, attack, damage, magic attack, magic damage, ect. Another plus is that this game actually has a story, unlike Terraria. The tooltips hint at a story, and you also have a book that fills itself in as you complete specific dungeons. It is a bit buggy, but the bugs are very minor. I give it a 7.8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												My pre-release review was a don't buy, wait and see, due to a few issues with the UI, controls, and bugs.  With the 1.0 release here, I've gone back and played a bit, and to be honest, I'm on the fence.With the exception of the "crafting" NPCs issue, there seems to have been improvements all around. The control scheme (UI) is better, I haven't encountered any bugs yet, and the skill progression appears much improved. I'll need to delve into it more to get better insight, but overall it is a better game now.However, better doesn't mean that there aren't much needed improvements/additions to be made.  Many similar games out now are focusing on adding things such as mechanical systems, power systems, vehicles, etc.  Compared to those games, this one seems priced a bit steep, as it incorporates none of that.  Sure, you can explore your world, go through dimensional rifts to smaller dynamic areas, and use magic, but most other games have that and then some.Then there's the issue of mining - now, I'm not sure if this changes with higher tier gear, but mining one block at a time is sort of a pain (NOTE: It has been confirmed that this is upgradable).Now, despite all of that, I still enjoy playing it for the most part - I enjoy the genre, unlocking skills, and exploration.  Plus, the game is still fairly new, thus could see all of these issues addressed.  Leading me to the dilemna of the recommendation - which unfortunately is still, wait & see...

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								While I like the concept. I find the game pretty freaking annoying. Once you go into placement mode, can't get out of it. I hit every key on was still stuck in it (most annoying feature).You build a workstation and then you don't know if you're supposed to access it or just be standing over it. I built a workstation, but I couldn't figure out how to access it, and standing right on it, I could still craft the same items. You have to swtch between combat and passive mode, however....You can only have 1 weapon equipped at a time. So if you have a bow and want to switch to a melee weapon it's a pain. You have to open your inventory and manually change weapons and hope you don't get killed in the process.I had no freaking clue how to use my shield to defend myself (lack of help info). Since there is a skill in there about moving while defending with your shield.There's no penalty for dying.You can cast heal on your self, but not in combat. So if you survive combat you can heal yourself.The hot keys and inventory are pretty small. 2 hot keys for weapons (really only 1, shield is equipped all the time). 5 for passive & 5 for spells.On the positive side you can level up your character and skills. However for me it's just not enough to get over the annoyances of the game (expecially placement mode).

content:

Early Access Review
								1/50th terrarias content with an arbitrary skill tree and dumbed down game play but much less fun. add nazi forum moderators who delete posts when its convenient and you have a real recipe for filth. this lady assclown (who is almost certainly a trannie named ted) or whatever her name is (forum mods are sub-human♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who has time to memorize their names?) literally removed every post i made, helpful or not.. after perma-banning me for telling some kid who "spelt lyket his" to learn english or not bother posting. hmm what was the last game to go that route? oh thats right, DARKOUT! this game will surely suffer the same fate.gotta love it when you support a game before its even on steam and the developers decide making a trip to pax (while delaying a MAJOR patch to do so) is a great idea when they arent even showing the game! like JUST there to rub e-peens and schmooze reporters.. love seeing money wasted on crap like this and then hearing about how tight budgets are and how much "work" has to be done (sitting on your duff typing=work? get a real job), and missed deadlines being part of the business.while it may seem like im attacking the developer and his crew (because i am) the fact remains this is a very boring game, most of terrarias appeal was it being action based and having little things like traps, this game has none of that. it has slightly better art (yea than a 16 bit game... what doesnt?) but in every other way the question is "why not play terraria?". multiplayer is buggy, the mobs are fully uninspired (slimes, and boars, and golems oh my! was the guy born with 0 creative bones in his body AT ALL?), and the digging is.. exactly as digging is in any other game. the soundtrack is boring, not just boring.. but the kind of boring that sounds like it should be heard in a room with a sleeping 3 month old baby. the crafting system is stupid (waste multiple pieces of a material to see what it can make.. then go get more of said material to actually MAKE said item and then waste that to see what IT can be used to make), and the selection of items is pathetic (1 dozen or so swords.. same for bows.. and armor.. nothing cool here at all). no boomerangs, no grappling hooks, theres really only even a rudimentary collection of building materials (which are kind of a pain to place).. it just plain reeks of mediocrity. avoid it.

Posted: March 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								DO NOT BUY THIS!I sat here for five fragging minutes trying to figure out how the HELL TO EVEN FIGHT.Starbound, Terraria, HELL... Exanima!These games are rather simple. Avoid getting hit.This? It gives no tutorial on how the hell to avoid attacks, to block or even use your spells. I understand you are level one, but for christs sake, EVEN OBLIVIONS FIRST FIREBALL COULD KILL A RAT!Waste your money if you like, its your choice and I did my duty as a gamer to warn others. SCREW THIS GAME.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Edit: post EA it doesn't seem to have fixed a lot of its issues that I thought would be quashed before official release. Unfortunately I can't recommend the game as it is, it lacks a point to it and feels grindy because there isn't really a goal (bosses, accomplish X/Y/Z). Perhaps future patches will fix it up, but for now, thumbs down. EA Review below.Terraria-like game with actual progression, based on what you do. Gathering increases your gathering skill which will give you points to improve your speed/power/etc while gathering. Same thing with combat, exploration, and crafting.Personally I REALLY love character-based progression, so this game clicked with me despite being a bit clunkly to play. I'd recommend giving it a try if you enjoy Terraria-like games (2D Minecraft), though I suspect that some people will not enjoy the level-based progression.Some cons would include a complaint here that archery feels bad (arrow drop is overtuned IMO), the starting stamina is really really bad, and I do wish there was some kind of quest-based progression as well (a la Terraria or Starbound). However, the game is in EA so it could very well improve over time.  So far, 7/10, I am satisfied with what I bought.
